content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="B94UDP3YGBQQRA3I47KZ" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>High-throughput Ab-initio Dilute Solute Diffusion Database</title><identifier>doi:10.18126/M2X59R</identifier><identifier>doi:10.1038/sdata.2016.54</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>Materials Data Facility</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Dane" sur="Morgan" xsi:type="PersonName">Dane Morgan</name></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Henry" sur="Wu" xsi:type="PersonName">Henry Wu</name></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Tam" sur="Mayeshiba" xsi:type="PersonName">Tam Mayeshiba</name><affiliation>Materials Science Program, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, Wisconsin 53706, USA</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Dane" sur="Morgan" xsi:type="PersonName">Dane Morgan</name><affiliation>Materials Science and Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, Wisconsin 53706, USA</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Dane Morgan</name><emailAddress>ddmorgan@wisc.edu</emailAddress><phoneNumber>(608) 265-5879</phoneNumber></contact></providers><content><description>We demonstrate automated generation of diffusion databases from high-throughput density functional theory (DFT) calculations. A total of more than 230 dilute solute diffusion systems in Mg, Al, Cu, Ni, Pd, and Pt host lattices have been determined using multi-frequency diffusion models. We apply a correction method for solute diffusion in alloys using experimental and simulated values of host self-diffusivity. We find good agreement with experimental solute diffusion data, obtaining a weighted activation barrier RMS error of 0.176 eV when excluding magnetic solutes in non-magnetic alloys. The compiled database is the largest collection of consistently calculated ab-initio solute diffusion data in the world.</description><subject>Atomistic models</subject><subject>Computational methods</subject><subject>Solute diffusion</subject><subject>Density functional theory</subject><subject>Computational Chemistry</subject><landingPage>https://www.nature.com/articles/sdata201654</landingPage><reference pid="doi:10.1038/sdata.2016.54">High-throughput ab-initio dilute solute diffusion database</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role The database is called “The American Mineralogist Crystal Structure Database” and is freely accessible from the websites of the Mineralogical Society of America at http://www.minsocam.org/MSA/Crystal_Database.html and the University of Arizona. In addition to the database, a suite of interactive software is provided that can be used to view and manipulate the crystal structures and compute different properties of a crystal such as geometry, diffraction patterns, and procrystal electron densities. The database is set up so that the data can be easily incorporated into other software packages. Included at the website is an evolving set of guides to instruct the user and help with classroom education.</description><subject>crystal structure</subject><subject>mineralogy</subject><subject>crystallography</subject><landingPage>http://rruff.geo.arizona.edu/AMS/amcsd.php</landingPage><reference content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="UFA1UE1QAH1U1X0Z3GQ5" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>X-ray scattering data for Polymorphism study of Gold 144 clusters</title><altTitle type="AlternativeTitle">ncomm-goldnp-2016: Release 3.0</altTitle><identifier>10.5281/zenodo.56682</identifier><identifier>10.1038/ncomms11859</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>Zenodo</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name label="IsSupplementTo" xsi:type="DciteRelation">Polymorphism in magic sized Au144(SR)60 clusters</name><affiliation></affiliation></creator><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="" given="Kirsten" sur="Jensen" xsi:type="PersonName">Kirsten Jensen</name><affiliation>Department of Applied Physics and Applied Mathematics, Columbia University, New York, New York 10027, USA</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="" given="Pavol" sur="Juhás" xsi:type="PersonName">Pavol Juhás</name><affiliation>Condensed Matter Physics and Materials Science Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York 11973, USA</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="" given="Marcus" sur="Tofanelli" xsi:type="PersonName">Marcus Tofanelli</name><affiliation>Department of Chemistry, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado 80523, USA</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="" given="Christine" sur="Heinecke" xsi:type="PersonName">Christine L. Heinecke</name><affiliation>Department of Chemistry, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado 80523, USA</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="" given="Christopher" sur="Ackerson" xsi:type="PersonName">Christopher Ackerson</name><affiliation>Department of Chemistry, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado 80523, USA</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="" given="Gavin" sur="Vaughn" xsi:type="PersonName">Gavin Vaughn</name><affiliation>European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, 38043 Grenoble, France</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="" given="Simon" sur="Billinge" xsi:type="PersonName">Simon J. L. Billinge</name><affiliation>Department of Applied Physics and Applied Mathematics, Columbia University, New York, New York 10027, USA</affiliation></contributor><contact><name>Simon J. L. Billinge</name><postalAddress><addressLine>Columbia University</addressLine></postalAddress><emailAddress>sb2896@columbia.edu</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>The datasets were measured from 5 different samples Au144(PET)60, Au144(SC4)60, Au144(SC6)60, Au144(SC12)60 and Au144(pMBA)60. All scattering data were measured at 100 K. The first 4 datasets were obtained at the 11-ID-B beamline of the Advanced Photon Source (APS), with a wavelength of 0.143 Å. The data are provided in plain text format as integrated total scattering intensities versus Q [1/nm] in .chi files and as reduced pair distribution functions (PDF-s) in .gr files. The data in Kapton_APS.chi are background scattering intensities to be used with the APS data. The last dataset, Au144pMBA_100K_ESRF, was obtained at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF) beamline ID11 using X-ray wavelength of 0.177 Å. 
The folder also contains atom coordinates for the 114-atom gold core and different staple configurations.</description><subject>nanoparticles</subject><subject>nanoclusters</subject><subject>polymorphism</subject><subject>nanoscale engineering</subject><subject>X-ray powder diffraction</subject><landingPage>https://github.com/sbillinge/ncomm-goldnp-2016/tree/v3.0</landingPage><reference pid="doi:10.1038/ncomms11859">Polymorphism in magic-sized Au144(SR)60 clusters</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><rights>Creative Commons Attribution 4.0</rights><termsURL>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="text/html">https://github.com/sbillinge/ncomm-goldnp-2016/tree/v3.0</accessURL><format></format></method></access></Resource>

title: BFCC-13.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="NN2PYC4V1LTHTEKMSGZN" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>DFT calculations for solid AgPd, CuPt and AgPt FCC superstructures</title><altTitle type="AlternativeTitle">Cluster expansion made easy with Bayesian compressive sensing</altTitle><altTitle type="AlternativeTitle">BFCC-13</altTitle><version></version><identifier>10.1103/PhysRevB.88.155105</identifier><logo></logo></identity><providers><publisher>American Physical Society (APS) Physics</publisher><publicationYear>2013</publicationYear><creator><name middle="J. " given="Lance" sur="Nelson" xsi:type="PersonName">Lance J. Nelson</name><affiliation>Department of Physics and Astronomy, Brigham Young University, Provo, Utah 84602, USA</affiliation></creator><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="J." given="Lance" sur="Nelson" xsi:type="PersonName">Lance J. Nelson</name><affiliation>Department of Physics and Astronomy, Brigham Young University, Provo, Utah 84602, USA</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="" given="Vidvuds" sur="Ozoliņš" xsi:type="PersonName">Vidvuds Ozoliņš</name><affiliation>Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, California 90095, USA</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="Shane" given="C." sur="Reese" xsi:type="PersonName">C. Shane Reese</name><affiliation>Department of Statistics, Brigham Young University, Provo, Utah 84602, USA</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="" given="Fei" sur="Zhou" xsi:type="PersonName">Fei Zhou</name><affiliation>Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, California 94550, USA</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="L.W." given="Gus" sur="Hart" xsi:type="PersonName">Gus L. W. Hart</name><affiliation>Department of Physics and Astronomy, Brigham Young University, Provo, Utah 84602, USA</affiliation></contributor><date role="Available" xsi:type="DciteDate">2013</date><contact><name>Gus L. W. Hart</name><postalAddress><addressLine>Dept. of Physics and Astronomy Brigham Young University N249 Eyring Science Center</addressLine></postalAddress><emailAddress>gus.hart@gmail.com</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Long-standing challenges in cluster expansion (CE) construction include choosing how to truncate the expansion and which crystal structures to use for training. Compressive sensing (CS), which is emerging as a powerful tool for model construction in physics, provides a mathematically rigorous framework for addressing these challenges. A recently-developed Bayesian implementation of CS (BCS) provides a parameterless framework, a vast speed-up over current CE construction techniques, and error estimates on model coefficients. Here, we demonstrate the use of BCS to build cluster expansion models for several binary alloy systems. The speed of the method and the accuracy of the resulting fits are shown to be far superior than state-of-the-art evolutionary methods for all alloy systems shown. When combined with high-throughput first-principles frameworks, the implications of BCS are that hundreds of lattice models can be automatically constructed, paving the way to high-throughput thermodynamic modeling of alloys.

G.L.W.H. and L.J.N. are grateful for financial support from the NSF, DMR-0908753. C.S.R. is grateful for financial support from the NSF, ATM-0934490. F.Z. and V.O. gratefully acknowledge financial support from the NSF under Award No. DMR-1106024 and use of computing resources at the National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center, which is supported by the US DOE under Contract No. DE-AC02- 05CH11231. F.Z. is supported by the US DOE under Contract No. DE-AC52-07NA27344.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>DFT calculations</subject><landingPage>http://qmml.org/datasets.html#solids</landingPage><reference pid="10.1103/PhysRevB.88.155105">Physical Review B, vol. 88, Issue 15</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="DataCollection"><type>Collection: Repository</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><dataOrigin><theory>theory</theory></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><structuralFeature></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale><computeScale><nanoscale>atomic scale (nanoscale)</nanoscale></computeScale><computeScale><structural>structural</structural></computeScale><synthesisProcessing></synthesisProcessing></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><rights></rights><termsURL></termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><title>BFCC-13</title><description>4000 DFT calculations for solid AgPd, CuPt and AgPt FCC superstructures. DFT/PBE energy, forces and stresses for cell sizes 1-16 across all compositions including primitive cells.</description><accessURL returns="bfcc-13.tar.bz2">http://qmml.org/datasets.html#solids</accessURL><format>bfcc-13.tar.bz2</format><filesize>1.18 GB</filesize></method></access></Resource>

title: Supplementary information for a study of DFT+U in the context of BiFeO3.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="3CD1IXSYNLX0L75DALGH" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Supplementary information for a study of DFT+U in the context of BiFeO3</title><altTitle type="AlternativeTitle">DFT+U study of BiFeO3 using VASP and pymatgen</altTitle><version>2.0</version><identifier>10.5281/zenodo.597611</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>Github.com</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><creator><name middle="Kane" given="John" sur="Shenton " xsi:type="PersonName">John Kane Shenton</name><affiliation>University College London: London, London, United Kingdom</affiliation></creator><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="Kane" given="John" sur="Shenton" xsi:type="PersonName">J. Kane Shenton</name><affiliation>Department of Physics and Astronomy, University College London, Gower St, London, WC1E 6BT</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="" given="David" sur="Bowler" xsi:type="PersonName">David R. Bowler</name><affiliation>Department of Physics and Astronomy, University College London, Gower St, London, WC1E 6BT</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="Researcher"><name middle="Li" given="Wei" sur="Cheah" xsi:type="PersonName">Wei Li Cheah</name><affiliation>Institute of High Performance Computing, A-STAR, Singapore</affiliation></contributor><contact><name>John Kane Shenton</name><emailAddress>john.shenton.10@ucl.ac.uk</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>This notebook makes use of the pymatgen package to display some of the characteristics and results of the VASP input and outputs in the study of DFT+U in bismuth ferrite. In this work we use the DFT+U method of Dudarev et al, which takes a single parameter Ueff=U−J. For simplicity however, we will simply use the symbol U in this notebook to refer to the Ueff parameter.</description><description>First principles studies of multiferroic materials, such as bismuth ferrite (BFO), require methods that extend beyond standard density functional theory (DFT). The DFT+U method is one such extension that is widely used in the study of BFO. We present a systematic study of the effects of the U parameter on the structural, ferroelectric and electronic properties of BFO. We find that the structural and ferroelectric properties change negligibly in the range of U typically considered for BFO (3-5 eV).In contrast, the electronic structure varies significantly with U. In particular, we see large changes to the character and curvature of the valence band maximum and conduction band minimum, in addition to the expected increase in band gap, as U increases. Most significantly, we find that the t2g-eg ordering at the conduction band minimum inverts for U values larger than 4 eV. We therefore recommend a U value of at most 4 eV to be applied to the Fe d orbitals in BFO. More generally, this study emphasises the need for systematic investigations of the effects of the U parameter not merely on band gaps but on the electronic structure as a whole, especially for strongly correlated materials.</description><subject>materials research</subject><subject>DFT</subject><landingPage>https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/jks-science/BFO_dftu_SI/blob/master/dft_u_BFO_SI.ipynb</landingPage><reference pid="10.1088/1361-648X/aa8935">Effects of the Hubbard U on density functional-based predictions of BiFeO3 properties</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys: Fe-containing</metals_and_alloys></materialType><structuralFeature></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical: band structure</electrical></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><rights>Open Access</rights></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><title>Supplementary information for a study of DFT+U in the context of BiFeO3</title><description>This notebook makes use of the pymatgen package to display some of the characteristics and results of the VASP input and outputs in the study of DFT+U in bismuth ferrite. In this work we use the DFT+U method of Dudarev et al, which takes a single parameter Ueff=U−J. For simplicity however, we will simply use the symbol U in this notebook to refer to the Ueff parameter.</description><accessURL returns="zip">https://zenodo.org/record/581302#.WWWmB8aZPFQ</accessURL><format>BFO_dftu_SI-v1.0.zip</format><filesize>124 MB</filesize></method></access></Resource>

title: Computation-Ready Experimental Metal-Organic Frameworks Database.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="FBLN79ZTW52BYJN47T7M" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Computation-Ready Experimental Metal-Organic Frameworks Database.</title><version>1.0</version><identifier>http://gregchung.github.io/research/2017/09/27/metal-organic-frameworks/</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>http://gregchung.github.io</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Yongchul" sur="Chung" xsi:type="PersonName">Chung, Yongchul G.</name><affiliation>Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, Illinois 60208, United States</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Chung, Yongchul G.</name><emailAddress>greg.chung@pusan.ac.kr</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of nanoporous crystalline materials that are synthesized in a building-block approach from inorganic secondary building units (SBUs) and organic linkers. The building-block paradigm to MOF synthesis creates opportunities for the synthesis of virtually unlimited number of nanoporous materials.
Metal-organic framework database

Thousands of the MOFs have been experimentally synthesized already since the discovery of the MOFs in the late 1990s. In practice, synthesizing and testing the large number of MOFs is not feasible, therefore, the high-throughput computational screening of a large database of MOFs can help expedite the experimental efforts. At the heart of high-throughput computational screening of MOFs is the database of MOFs.</description><subject>Materials research</subject><landingPage>http://gregchung.github.io/research/2017/09/27/metal-organic-frameworks/</landingPage><reference pid="10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b04226">Large-Scale Refinement of Metal Organic Framework Structures Using DFT</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset: Database</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><propertyAddressed></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><nanoscale>atomic scale (nanoscale)</nanoscale></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction></policy></access></Resource>

title: The Coherent X-ray Imaging Data Bank.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="7UHIRI48BY5AE9D43NIB" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>The Coherent X-ray Imaging Data Bank</title><identifier></identifier></identity><providers><publisher>Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Filipe" sur="Maia" xsi:type="PersonName">Maia, Filipe</name><affiliation>Lawrence Berkeley National Lab 1 Cyclotron Road Mail Stop 943-256, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Maia, Filipe</name><emailAddress>cxidb@cxidb.org</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Welcome to the Coherent X-ray Imaging Data Bank (CXIDB), a new database which offers scientists from all over the world a unique opportunity to access data from Coherent X-ray Imaging (CXI) experiments.
• New light sources and detectors have enabled novel experiments producing terabytes of data per day.
• It's the dawn of the data deluge era for coherent X-ray imaging.
• To best make use of all these data it is necessary to make them accessible.
Accessibility is crucial not only to make efficient use of experimental facilities, but also to improve the reproducibility of results and enable new research based on previous experiments.
CXIDB is dedicated to further the goal of making data from Coherent X-ray Imaging (CXI) experiments available to all, as well as archiving it. The website also serves as the reference for the CXI file format, in which most of the experimental data on the database is stored in.</description><subject></subject><landingPage>http://cxidb.org/index.html</landingPage><reference pid="">Maia, Fillipe, The Coherent X-ray Imaging Data Bank. Nat. Methods 9, 854–855 (2012).</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><materialType></materialType><characterizationMethod><scattering_and_diffraction>scattering and diffraction</scattering_and_diffraction></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><scattering_and_diffraction>scattering and diffraction: x-ray diffraction</scattering_and_diffraction></characterizationMethod></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><rights></rights><termsURL>open</termsURL><copyright><crholder></crholder></copyright></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="text/html">http://cxidb.org/</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="A2TS7MX55CM2LD6NSHA7" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Theoretical Investigations and Density Functional Theory Based Quantitative Structure–Activity Relationships Model for Novel Cytotoxic Platinum(IV) Complexes</title><version></version><identifier></identifier></identity><providers><publisher>American Chemical Society</publisher><publicationYear>2015</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="" sur="" xsi:type="PersonName">Hristo P. Varbanov</name><affiliation>Institute of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Vienna, Währinger Strasse 42, A-1090 Vienna, Austria</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="" sur="" xsi:type="PersonName">Michael A. Jakupec</name><affiliation>Institute of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Vienna, Währinger Strasse 42, A-1090 Vienna, Austria</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="" sur="" xsi:type="PersonName">Alexander Roller</name><affiliation>Institute of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Vienna, Währinger Strasse 42, A-1090 Vienna, Austria</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="" sur="" xsi:type="PersonName">Frank Jensen</name><affiliation>Department of Chemistry, University of Aarhus, Langelandgade 140, 8000 Aarhus C, Denmark</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Markus" sur="Galanski" xsi:type="PersonName">Markus Galanski</name><affiliation>Institute of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Vienna, Währinger Strasse 42, A-1090 Vienna, Austria</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Bernhard" sur="Keppler" xsi:type="PersonName">Bernhard K. Keppler</name><affiliation>Institute of Inorganic Chemistry, University of Vienna, Währinger Strasse 42, A-1090 Vienna, Austria</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Frank Jensen</name><emailAddress>frj@chem.au.dk</emailAddress></contact><contact><name>Markus Galanski</name><emailAddress>markus.galanski@univie.ac.at</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Octahedral platinum(IV) complexes are promising candidates in the fight against cancer. In order to rationalize the further development of this class of compounds, detailed studies on their mechanisms of action, toxicity, and resistance must be provided and structure–activity relationships must be drawn. Herein, we report on theoretical and QSAR investigations of a series of 53 novel bis-, tris-, and tetrakis(carboxylato)platinum(IV) complexes, synthesized and tested for cytotoxicity in our laboratories. The hybrid DFT functional wb97x was used for optimization of the structure geometry and calculation of the descriptors. Reliable and robust QSAR models with good explanatory and predictive properties were obtained for both the cisplatin sensitive cell line CH1 and the intrinsically cisplatin resistant cell line SW480, with a set of four descriptors.</description><subject>DFT</subject><subject>Platinum(IV) Complexes</subject><subject></subject><landingPage>https://figshare.com/articles/Theoretical_Investigations_and_Density_Functional_Theory_Based_Quantitative_Structure_Activity_Relationships_Model_for_Novel_Cytotoxic_Platinum_IV_Complexes/2022036</landingPage><reference pid="10.1021/jm3016427">Theoretical Investigations and Density Functional Theory Based Quantitative Structure–Activity Relationships Model for Novel Cytotoxic Platinum(IV) Complexes</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><propertyAddressed></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="https://figshare.com/articles/Theoretical_Investigations_and_Density_Functional_Theory_Based_Quantitative_Structure_Activity_Relationships_Model_for_Novel_Cytotoxic_Platinum_IV_Complexes/2022036"></accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: doak_strain_energies.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="5GMQ5HEQ94OCXWKGXM91" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Non-self-consistent Density-Functional Theory Exchange-Correlation Forces for GGA Functionals</title><identifier>article</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>ACS Publications</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Antonio" sur="Torralba" xsi:type="PersonName">Antonio S. Torralba</name><affiliation>London Centre for Nanotechnology, UCL, 17-19 Gordon St, London WC1H 0AH, U.K., and Materials Simulation</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="David" sur="Bowler" xsi:type="PersonName">David R. Bowler</name><affiliation>London Centre for Nanotechnology, UCL, 17-19 Gordon St, London WC1H 0AH, U.K., and Materials Simulation</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Tsuyoshi" sur="Miyazaki" xsi:type="PersonName">Tsuyoshi Miyazaki</name><affiliation>Laboratory and Department of Physics and Astronomy, UCL, Gower St, London WC1E 6BT, and National Institute for Materials Science, 1-2-1 Sengen, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-0045, JAPAN</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Michael" sur="Gillan" xsi:type="PersonName">Michael J. Gillan</name><affiliation>London Centre for Nanotechnology, UCL, 17-19 Gordon St, London WC1H 0AH, U.K., and Materials Simulation</affiliation></creator><date role="Submitted" xsi:type="DciteDate">2017</date><contact><name>Antonio S. Torralba</name><emailAddress>TORRALBA.Antonio@nims.go.jp</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>When using density functional theory (DFT), generalized gradient approximation (GGA) functionals are often necessary for accurate modeling of important properties of biomolecules, including hydrogen-bond strengths and relative energies of conformers. We consider the calculations of forces using non-self-consistent (NSC) methods based on the Harris−Foulkes expression for energy. We derive an expression for the GGA NSC force on atoms, valid for a hierarchy of methods based on local orbitals, and discuss its implementation in the linear scaling DFT code Conquest, using a standard (White−Bird) approach. We investigate the use of NSC structural relaxations before full self-consistent relaxations as a method for improving convergence. Example calculations for glycine and small alanine peptides suggest that NSC pre-relaxations of the structure are indeed useful to save computer effort and time.</description><subject>DFT</subject><subject>alanine peptides</subject><subject>GGA Functionals</subject><landingPage>https://figshare.com/articles/Non_self_consistent_Density_Functional_Theory_Exchange_Correlation_Forces_for_GGA_Functionals/2851375</landingPage><reference pid="10.1021/ct8005425">J. Chem. Theory Comput., 2009, 5 (6), pp 1499–1505</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><organic_compounds>organic compounds</organic_compounds></materialType><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/us/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="text/html">https://figshare.com/articles/Non_self_consistent_Density_Functional_Theory_Exchange_Correlation_Forces_for_GGA_Functionals/2851375</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: doak_strain_energies.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="KLHKB5FKVU9YTH2QYQGQ" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>GeTe-PbTe PbS-PbTe PbSe-PbS PbTe-PbSe PbTe-SnTe SnTe-GeTe mixing and coherency strain energies</title><identifier>http://hdl.handle.net/11256/85</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>APS</publisher><publicationYear>2012</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Doak, Jeff W." sur="Doak, Jeff W." xsi:type="PersonName">Doak, Jeff W.</name><affiliation>Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, Illinois, USA 60208</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="C" sur="Wolverton" xsi:type="PersonName">Wolverton C</name><affiliation>Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, Illinois, USA 60208</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Doak, Jeff W.</name><emailAddress>jeff.w.doak@gmail.com</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Nanostructures formed by phase separation improve the thermoelectric figure of merit in lead chalcogenide semiconductor alloys, with coherent nanostructures giving larger improvements than incoherent nanostructures. However, large coherency strains in these alloys drastically alter the thermodynamics of phase stability. Incoherent phase stability can be easily inferred from an equilibrium phase diagram, but coherent phase stability is more difficult to assess experimentally. Therefore, we use density functional theory calculations to investigate the coherent and incoherent phase stability of the IV–VI rocksalt semiconductor alloy systems Pb(S,Te), Pb(Te,Se), Pb(Se,S), (Pb,Sn)Te, (Sn,Ge)Te, and (Ge,Pb)Te. Herewe use the term coherent to indicate that there is a common and unbroken lattice between the phases under consideration, and we use the term incoherent to indicate that the lattices of coexisting phases are unconstrained and allowed to take on equilibrium volumes.We find that the thermodynamic ground state of all of the IV–VI pseudobinary systems studied is incoherent phase separation. We also find that the coherency strain energy, previously neglected in studies of these IV–VI alloys, is lowest along [111] (in contrast to most fcc metals) and is a large fraction of the thermodynamic driving force for incoherent phase separation in all systems. The driving force for coherent phase separation is significantly reduced, and we find that coherent nanostructures can only form at lowtemperatureswhere kinetics may prohibit their precipitation. Furthermore, by calculating the energies of ordered structures for these systems we find that the coherent phase stability of most IV–VI systems favors ordering over spinodal decomposition. Our results suggest that experimental reports of spinodal decomposition in the IV–VI rocksalt alloys should be re-examined.</description><subject>Materials research</subject><subject>Nanostructures</subject><subject>Alloys</subject><landingPage>https://materialsdata.nist.gov/dspace/xmlui/handle/11256/85</landingPage><reference pid="10.1103/PhysRevB.86.144202">Coherent and incoherent phase stabilities of thermoelectric rocksalt IV-VI semiconductor alloys. Phys. Rev. B 86: 144202</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><materialType><semiconductors>semiconductors</semiconductors></materialType><structuralFeature><phases>phases</phases></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><crystallographic>crystallographic</crystallographic></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><thermodynamic>thermodynamic</thermodynamic></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><title>Data Citation: Doak, Jeff W.; Wolverton, C. GeTe-PbTe PbS-PbTe PbSe-PbS PbTe-PbSe PbTe-SnTe SnTe-GeTe mixing and coherency strain energies</title><accessURL returns="text/html">https://materialsdata.nist.gov/dspace/xmlui/handle/11256/85</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

centered on known bulk compositions. The data are composed of two individual studies. The first set of data is a low temperature oxidation study on composition spread sampled performed at SLAC Beamline 1-5. Only the integrated and background subtracted 1-D spectra are included, the 2-D data and calibrations are available upon request. The second set of data was taken during high temperature oxidation of selected samples. These data are exclusively Raman data with values taken as a function of total oxidation time.</description><subject>Materials research</subject><subject>Alloys</subject><landingPage>https://materialsdata.nist.gov/dspace/xmlui/handle/11256/836</landingPage><reference pid="10.1088/0957-4484/26/27/274003">http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0957-4484/26/27/274003/meta</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys: Al-containing</metals_and_alloys></materialType><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys: Fe-containing</metals_and_alloys></materialType><structuralFeature><phases>phases</phases></structuralFeature><characterizationMethod><scattering_and_diffraction>scattering and diffraction</scattering_and_diffraction></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><scattering_and_diffraction>scattering and diffraction: small angle x-ray scattering</scattering_and_diffraction></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><spectroscopy>spectroscopy: Raman</spectroscopy></characterizationMethod><computeScale><nanoscale>atomic scale (nanoscale)</nanoscale></computeScale><computeScale><structural>structural</structural></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/us/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://materialsdata.nist.gov/dspace/xmlui/handle/11256/836</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: gw_soc81.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="24TS884OUKDIRES9IG8L" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Benchmark of G0W0 on 81 Molecules with Spin-Orbit Coupling</title><version></version><identifier></identifier></identity><providers><publisher>WEST Data Collections</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Peter" sur="Scherpelz" xsi:type="PersonName">Peter Scherpelz</name><affiliation>Institute for Molecular Engineering, The University of Chicago, Chicago, Illinois 60637, United States</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Marco" sur="Govoni" xsi:type="PersonName">Marco Govoni</name><affiliation>Institute for Molecular Engineering, The University of Chicago, Chicago, Illinois 60637, United States</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Ikutaro" sur="Hamada" xsi:type="PersonName">Ikutaro Hamada</name><affiliation>National Institute for Materials Science, 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba 305-0044, Japan</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Giulia" sur="Galli" xsi:type="PersonName">Giulia Galli</name><affiliation>Institute for Molecular Engineering, The University of Chicago, Chicago, Illinois 60637, United States</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Peter Scherpelz</name><emailAddress>pscherpelz@uchicago.edu</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>This is a benchmark of G0W0 on 81 molecules, introduced for testing the implementation of G0W0 calculations including spin-orbit coupling (SOC). Each molecule has at least one heavy element (Z≥29). For each molecule, the Vertical Ionization Potential (VIP) is computed with the WEST code, using fully-relativistic (FR) and scalar-relativistic (SR) pseudopotentials. Experimental results of VIPs are also reported.

We present an implementation of G0W0 calculations including spin–orbit coupling (SOC) enabling investigations of large systems, with thousands of electrons, and we discuss results for molecules, solids, and nanocrystals. Using a newly developed set of molecules with heavy elements (called GW-SOC81), we find that, when based upon hybrid density functional calculations, fully relativistic (FR) and scalar-relativistic (SR) G0W0 calculations of vertical ionization potentials both yield excellent performance compared to experiment, with errors below 1.9%. We demonstrate that while SR calculations have higher random errors, FR calculations systematically underestimate the VIP by 0.1 to 0.2 eV. We further verify that SOC effects may be well approximated at the FR density functional level and then added to SR G0W0 results for a broad class of systems. We also address the use of different root-finding algorithms for the G0W0 quasiparticle equation and the significant influence of including d electrons in the valence partition of the pseudopotential for G0W0 calculations. Finally, we present statistical analyses of our data, highlighting the importance of separating definitive improvements from those that may occur by chance due to a limited number of samples. We suggest the statistical analyses used here will be useful in the assessment of the accuracy of a large variety of electronic structure methods.</description><subject>Materials science</subject><subject>WEST code</subject><subject>density functional calculations</subject><subject>DFT</subject><landingPage>http://www.west-code.org/database/gwsoc81/index.php#ref001</landingPage><reference pid="10.1021/acs.jctc.6b00114">Implementation and Validation of Fully Relativistic GW Calculations: Spin–Orbit Coupling in Molecules, Nanocrystals, and Solids</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><ceramics>ceramics</ceramics></materialType><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><materialType><semiconductors>semiconductors</semiconductors></materialType><structuralFeature></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale><computeScale><nanoscale>atomic scale (nanoscale)</nanoscale></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><description>This is a benchmark of G0W0 on 81 molecules, introduced for testing the implementation of G0W0 calculations including spin-orbit coupling (SOC). Each molecule has at least one heavy element (Z≥29). For each molecule, the Vertical Ionization Potential (VIP) is computed with the WEST code, using fully-relativistic (FR) and scalar-relativistic (SR) pseudopotentials. Experimental results of VIPs are also reported.</description><accessURL returns="">http://www.west-code.org/database/gwsoc81/index.php#ref001</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: gw100.xml

title: c_n_photocatalysts2.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="XOL7PMJFNQ5NH1IA2EA0" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Data for article: Time-Resolved Spectroscopic Investigation of Charge Trapping in Carbon Nitrides Photocatalysts for Hydrogen Generation</title><identifier>10.5281/zenodo.400776</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>Zenodo</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Yiou" sur="Wang" xsi:type="PersonName">Wang, Yiou</name><affiliation>Group of Solar Energy and Advanced Materials, Department of Chemical Engineering, University College London, Torrington Place, London WC1E 7JE, U.K.</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Martijn" sur="Zwijnenburg" xsi:type="PersonName">Zwijnenburg, Martijn A.</name><affiliation>Department of Chemistry, University College London, 20 Gordon Street, London WC1H 0AJ, U.K.</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Junwang" sur="Tang" xsi:type="PersonName">Tang, Junwang</name><affiliation>Group of Solar Energy and Advanced Materials, Department of Chemical Engineering, University College London, Torrington Place, London WC1E 7JE, U.K.</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="James" sur="Durrant" xsi:type="PersonName">Durrant, James R.</name><affiliation>Department of Chemistry and Centre for Plastic Electronics, Imperial College London, South Kensington Campus, London SW7 2AZ, U.K.</affiliation></creator><contact><name>James R. Durrant</name><emailAddress>j.durrant@imperial.ac.uk</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>This is the data presented in the article titled 'Time-Resolved Spectroscopic Investigation of Charge Trapping in Carbon Nitrides Photocatalysts for Hydrogen Generation', published in the Journal of the American Chemical Society.

Carbon nitride (g-C3N4) as a benchmark polymer photocatalyst is attracting significant research interest because of its visible light photocatalytic performance combined with good stability and facile synthesis. However, little is known about the fundamental photophysical processes of g-C3N4, which are key to explain and promote photoactivity. Using time-resolved absorption and photoluminescence spectroscopies, we have investigated the photophysics of a series of carbon nitrides on time scales ranging from femtoseconds to seconds. Free charge carriers form within a 200 fs excitation pulse, trap on the picosecond time scale with trap states in a range of energies, and then recombine with power law decays that are indicative of charge trapping–detrapping processes. Delayed photoluminescence is assigned to thermal excitation of trapped carriers back up to the conduction/valence bands. We develop a simple, quantitative model for the charge carrier dynamics in these photocatalysts, which includes carrier relaxation into an exponential tail of trap states extending up to 1.5 eV into the bandgap. This trapping reduces the efficiency of surface photocatalytic reactions. Deep trapped electrons observed on micro- to millisecond time scales are unable to reduce electron acceptors on the surface or in solution. Within a series of g-C3N4, the yield of these unreactive trapped electrons correlates inversely with H2 evolution rates. We conclude by arguing that the photophysics of these carbon nitride materials show closer parallels with inorganic semiconductors than conjugated polymers, and that the key challenge to optimize photocatalytic activity of these materials is to prevent electron trapping into deep, and photocatalytically inactive, electron trap states.</description><subject>Materials research</subject><subject>Carbon Nitride</subject><subject>Photoluminescence</subject><subject>Time-Resolved Spectroscopy</subject><landingPage>https://zenodo.org/record/400776</landingPage><reference pid="pid: 10.1021/jacs.7b01547">Time-Resolved Spectroscopic Investigation of Charge Trapping in Carbon Nitrides Photocatalysts for Hydrogen Generation</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><semiconductors>semiconductors</semiconductors></materialType><structuralFeature></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><optical>optical: photoconductivity</optical></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</termsURL><copyright><crholder></crholder></copyright></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://zenodo.org/record/400776</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="XBMPSWKAJPR3H3EDV0QE" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>JARVIS - Joint Automated Repository for Various Integrated Simulations</title><altTitle type="Subtitle">JARVIS-FF</altTitle><altTitle type="Subtitle">JARVIS-DFT</altTitle><altTitle type="Subtitle">JARVIS-ML</altTitle></identity><providers><publisher>NIST</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Kamal" sur="Choudhary" xsi:type="PersonName">Kamal Choudhary</name><affiliation>National Institute of Standards and Technology</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Faical" sur="Congo" xsi:type="PersonName">Faical Y. Congo</name><affiliation>National Institute of Standards and Technology</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Chandler" sur="Becker" xsi:type="PersonName">Chandler A. Becker</name></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Francesca" sur="Tavazza" xsi:type="PersonName">Francesca M. Tavazza</name><affiliation>National Institute of Standards and Technology</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Kamal Choudhary</name><emailAddress>kamal.choudhary@nist.gov</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>JARVIS (Joint Automated Repository for Various Integrated Simulations) is a repository designed to automate materials discovery using classical force-field, density functional theory, machine learning calculations and experiments.

The Force-field section of JARVIS (JARVIS-FF) consists of thousands of automated LAMMPS based force-field calculations on DFT geometries. Some of the properties included in JARVIS-FF are energetics, elastic constants, surface energies, defect formations energies and phonon frequencies of materials.

The Density functional theory section of JARVIS (JARVIS-DFT) consists of thousands of VASP based calculations for 3D-bulk, single layer (2D), nanowire (1D) and molecular (0D) systems. Most of the calculations are carried out with optB88vDW functional. JARVIS-DFT includes materials data such as: energetics, diffraction pattern, radial distribution function, band-structure, density of states, carrier effective mass, temperature and carrier concentration dependent thermoelectric properties, elastic constants and gamma-point phonons.

The Machine-learning section of JARVIS (JARVIS-ML) consists of machine learning prediction tools, trained on JARVIS-DFT data. Some of the ML-predictions focus on energetics, heat of formation, GGA/METAGGA bandgaps, bulk and shear modulus.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Empirical Potentials</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><subject>Energetics properties</subject><subject>Elastic properties</subject><landingPage>http://www.ctcms.nist.gov/~knc6/periodic.html</landingPage><reference pid="10.1038/sdata.2016.125">Evaluation and comparison of classical interatomic potentials title: cyclopropenes2.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="114TN7A8PNLUZQV7EBMF" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Heptamethyl Indenyl (Ind*) Enables Diastereoselective Benzamidation of Cyclopropenes via Rh(III)-Catalyzed C-H Activation</title></identity><providers><publisher>Zenodo</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Robert" sur="Paton" xsi:type="PersonName">Paton, Robert</name><affiliation>Chemistry Research Laboratory, University of Oxford, Mansfield Road, Oxford OX1 3TA, UK</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Kelvin" sur="Jackson" xsi:type="PersonName">Jackson, Kelvin</name><affiliation>Chemistry Research Laboratory, University of Oxford, Mansfield Road, Oxford OX1 3TA, UK</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Paton, Robert</name><emailAddress>robert.paton@chem.ox.ac.uk</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>The diastereoselective coupling of O-substituted arylhydroxamates and cyclopropenes mediated by Rh(III) catalysis was successfully developed. Through ligand development, the diastereoselectivity of this reaction was improved using a heptamethylindenyl (Ind*) ligand, which has been rationalized using quantum chemical calculations. In addition, the nature of the O-substituted ester of benzhydroxamic acid proved important for high diastereoselectivity. This transformation tolerates a variety of benzamides and cyclopropenes that furnish cyclopropa[c]dihydroisoquinolones with high diastereocontrol, which could then be easily transformed into synthetically useful building blocks for pharmaceuticals and bio-active molecules.

Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed with Gaussian09 rev D.01. The meta-generalized gradient approximations (meta-GGA) TPSS exchange-correlation functional was used for all geometry optimizations with density fitting for Coulomb integrals (RI-J), a fine integration grid and the Karlsruhe def2-TZVP basis set for all elements.</description><subject>DFT</subject><subject>Transition State</subject><subject>Stereoselectivity</subject><landingPage>https://zenodo.org/record/53736</landingPage><reference pid="10.1039/C6SC02587K">Heptamethylindenyl (Ind*) enables diastereoselective benzamidation of cyclopropenes via Rh(III)-catalyzed C–H activation</reference></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><organic_compounds>organic compounds</organic_compounds></materialType><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><title>Heptamethyl Indenyl (Ind*) Enables Diastereoselective Benzamidation of Cyclopropenes via Rh(III)-Catalyzed C-H Activation</title><accessURL returns="text/html">https://zenodo.org/record/53736#.WWWmjMaZPFQ</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: high_pressure_ba_cro3.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="3Q20XWSFR9ROMD8FM0FH" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>BaCrO3-x JSSC 2015</title><identifier>10.7488/ds/305</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>University of Edinburgh School of Chemistry</publisher><publicationYear>2015</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Paul" sur="Attfield" xsi:type="PersonName">Attfield, J. Paul</name><affiliation>University of Edinburgh School of Chemistry</affiliation></creator><contributor role="DataCollector"><name label="IsPartOf" xsi:type="DciteRelation">EPSRC - Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council</name></contributor><contact><name>Attfield, J. Paul</name><emailAddress>j.p.attfield@ed.ac.uk</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>High-pressure BaCrO3 polytypes and the 5H–BaCrO2.8 phase paper abstract:
Polytypism of BaCrO3 perovskites has been investigated at 900–1100 °C and pressures up to 22 GPa. Hexagonal 5H, 4H, and 6H perovskites are observed with increasing pressure, and the cubic 3C perovskite (a=3.99503(1) Å) is observed in bulk form for the first time at 19–22 GPa. An oxygen-deficient material with limiting composition 5H–BaCrO2.8 is synthesised at 1200 °C under ambient pressure. This contains double tetrahedral Cr4+ layers and orders antiferromagnetically below 260 K with a (0 0 1/2) magnetic structure.</description><subject>X-ray diffraction crystallography</subject><subject>Powder neutron diffraction</subject><subject>Barium</subject><landingPage>http://datashare.is.ed.ac.uk/handle/10283/862</landingPage><reference pid="doi:10.1016/j.jssc.2015.09.029">Arévalo-López, AM; Attfield, JP (2015) "High-pressure BaCrO3 polytypes and the 5H–BaCrO2.8 phase" Journal of Solid State Chemistry</reference></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><rights>Creative Commons License: Attribution 4.0 International</rights><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><title>BaCrO3Data</title><accessURL returns="text/html, application/x-zip">http://datashare.is.ed.ac.uk/handle/10283/862</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

It is anticipated that this dataset will be of use in both relating electronic structure calculations to experimental observations through the generation of calibration schemes, as well as for the creation of new semi-empirical methods and the benchmarking of current and future model chemistries for organic electronic applications.</description><subject>Quantum chemical calculations</subject><subject>Density functional theory</subject><landingPage>https://www.nature.com/articles/sdata201686</landingPage><reference pid="">Scientific Data 3, Article number: 160086 (2016)</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><organic_compounds>organic compounds</organic_compounds></materialType><structuralFeature></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><chemical>chemical</chemical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><characterizationMethod></characterizationMethod><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale><synthesisProcessing></synthesisProcessing></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><title>The Harvard organic photovoltaic dataset</title><accessURL returns="">https://www.nature.com/articles/sdata201686#supplementary-information</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: ionic_radii_curie_temp.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="2HD9VD4KTTDZEAXWC6VA" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Effect of ionic radii on the Curie temperature in Ba1-x-ySrxCayTiO3 compounds</title><identifier>10.5281/zenodo.53983</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>Zenodo</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Andrey" sur=" Berenov" xsi:type="PersonName">Berenov, Andrey</name><affiliation>Department of Materials, Imperial College London, London, SW7 2AZ, UK</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Florian" sur="Le Goupil" xsi:type="PersonName">Le Goupil, Florian</name><affiliation>Department of Materials, Imperial College London, London, SW7 2AZ, UK</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Neil" sur="Alford" xsi:type="PersonName">Alford, Neil</name><affiliation>Department of Materials, Imperial College London, London, SW7 2AZ, UK</affiliation></creator><contact><name></name></contact></providers><content><description>A series of Ba1-x-ySrxCayTiO3 compounds were prepared with varying average ionic radii and cation disorder on A-site. All samples showed typical ferroelectric behavior. A simple empirical equation correlated Curie temperature, TC, with the values of ionic radii of A-site cations. This correlation was related to the distortion of TiO6 octahedra observed during neutron diffraction studies. The equation was used for the selection of compounds with predetermined values of TC. The effects of A-site ionic radii on the temperatures of phase transitions in Ba1-x-ySrxCayTiO3 were discussed.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Neutron diffraction</subject><subject>Phase transitions</subject><subject>Perovskites</subject><landingPage>https://zenodo.org/record/53983#.WWbODcaZPFQ</landingPage><reference pid="10.1038/srep28055">Effect of ionic radii on the Curie temperature in Ba1-x-ySrxCayTiO3 compounds</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><materialType><ceramics>ceramics</ceramics></materialType><materialType><ceramics>ceramics: perovskites</ceramics></materialType><structuralFeature><phases>phases: crystalline</phases></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical: dielectric constant and spectra</electrical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical: piezoelectric</electrical></propertyAddressed><characterizationMethod><scattering_and_diffraction>scattering and diffraction</scattering_and_diffraction></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><scattering_and_diffraction>scattering and diffraction: neutron [elastic]</scattering_and_diffraction></characterizationMethod><synthesisProcessing><solidification>solidification</solidification></synthesisProcessing></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><title>Effect of ionic radii on the Curie temperature in Ba1-x-ySrxCayTiO3 compounds</title><accessURL returns="">https://zenodo.org/record/53983#.WWbODcaZPFQ</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: irradiated_pyrochlores_ml.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="7LP4PER0HDE6FCPXN04O" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Using machine learning to identify factors that govern amorphization of irradiated pyrochlores</title><identifier></identifier></identity><providers><publisher>FigShare</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Ghanshyam" sur="Pilania" xsi:type="PersonName">Ghanshyam Pilania</name><affiliation>Materials Science and Technology Division, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, New Mexico 87545, United States</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Karl" sur="Whittle" xsi:type="PersonName">Karl R. Whittle</name><affiliation>School of Engineering, University of Liverpool, Liverpool L69 3BX, United Kingdom</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Chao" sur="Jiang" xsi:type="PersonName">Chao Jiang</name><affiliation>Fuels Modeling and Simulation Department, Idaho National Laboratory, Idaho Falls, Idaho 83415, United States</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Robin" sur="Grimes" xsi:type="PersonName">Robin W. Grimes</name><affiliation>Department of Materials, Imperial College London, London SW7 2AZ, United Kingdom</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="" sur="" xsi:type="PersonName">Christopher R. Stanek</name><affiliation>Materials Science and Technology Division, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, New Mexico 87545, United States</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Kurt" sur="Sickafus" xsi:type="PersonName">Kurt E. Sickafus</name><affiliation>Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, Tennessee 37996, United States</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Blas" sur="Uberuaga" xsi:type="PersonName">Blas Pedro Uberuaga</name><affiliation>Materials Science and Technology Division, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, New Mexico 87545, United States</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Blas Pedro Uberuaga</name><emailAddress>blas@lanl.gov</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Structure–property relationships are a key materials science concept that enables the design of new materials. In the case of materials for application in radiation environments, correlating radiation tolerance with fundamental structural features of a material enables materials discovery. Here, we use a machine learning model to examine the factors that govern amorphization resistance in the complex oxide pyrochlore (A2B2O7) in a regime in which amorphization occurs as a consequence of defect accumulation. We examine the fidelity of predictions based on cation radii and electronegativities, the oxygen positional parameter, and the energetics of disordering and amorphizing the material. No one factor alone adequately predicts amorphization resistance. We find that when multiple families of pyrochlores (with different B cations) are considered, radii and electronegativities provide the best prediction, but when the machine learning model is restricted to only the B = Ti pyrochlores, the energetics of disordering and amorphization are critical factors. We discuss how these static quantities provide insight into an inherently kinetic property such as amorphization resistance at finite temperature. This work provides new insight into the factors that govern the amorphization susceptibility and highlights the ability of machine learning approaches to generate that insight.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Machine Learning</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><subject>Amorphisation Resistance</subject><landingPage>https://figshare.com/articles/Using_Machine_Learning_To_Identify_Factors_That_Govern_Amorphization_of_Irradiated_Pyrochlores/4724158</landingPage><reference pid="10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b04666">Using Machine Learning To Identify Factors That Govern Amorphization of Irradiated Pyrochlores, Chem. Mater., 2017, 29 (6), pp 2574–2583</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><ceramics>ceramics</ceramics></materialType><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><materialType><semiconductors>semiconductors</semiconductors></materialType><structuralFeature><defects>defects</defects></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><crystallographic>crystallographic</crystallographic></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><nanoscale>atomic scale (nanoscale)</nanoscale></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/</termsURL></policy></access></Resource>

title: jcap_xps_spectral_db.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="AY74LXPTLZTE17XPZ2R3" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>JCAP XPS Spectral Database</title><altTitle type="AlternativeTitle">Materials Characterization Standards (MatChS) database</altTitle><identifier></identifier></identity><providers><publisher>California Institute of Technology, Joint Center for Artificial Photosynthesis (JCAP)</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><contact><name></name><emailAddress>info@solarfuelshub.org</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>The JCAP High Throughput Experimentation research team uses combinatorial methods to quickly identify promising light absorbers and catalysts for solar-fuel devices. Pure-phase materials — including metal oxides, nitrides, sulfides, oxinitrides, and other single- and mixed-metal materials — are prepared using multiple deposition techniques (e.g., physical vapor deposition, inkjet printing, and micro-fabrication) on various substrates. High-resolution X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra for materials that have been characterized to date are made available here as part of JCAP's Materials Characterization Standards (MatChS) database.</description><subject>Materials Research</subject><subject>X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy</subject><subject>Solar-fuel Devices</subject><landingPage>https://solarfuelshub.org/xps-spectral-database</landingPage><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><materialType><semiconductors>semiconductors</semiconductors></materialType><propertyAddressed><chemical>chemical</chemical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><optical>optical</optical></propertyAddressed><characterizationMethod><spectroscopy>spectroscopy: XPS variable kinetic</spectroscopy></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><spectroscopy>spectroscopy: x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy</spectroscopy></characterizationMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale><computeScale><nanoscale>atomic scale (nanoscale)</nanoscale></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction></policy><method xsi:type="PortalMethod"><title>XPS Spectral Database</title><description>High-resolution X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra.</description><accessURL returns="">https://solarfuelshub.org/xps-spectral-database/</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="BJ8PCYJUXR79Y8S8BZEE" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Materials Commons Data</title></identity><providers><publisher>PRISMS Center, at the University of Michigan</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><date role="Valid" xsi:type="DciteDate">2017</date><contact><name>John Allison</name><emailAddress>help@materialcommons.org</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Materials Commons is ...
An information repository - a collection of datafiles, measurement and analysis results, process description; organized for use, comprehension, and publication.
A data-and-process life-cycle record - Experiments, computation, and their results are described, monitored, and published.
A workflow record - workflow steps such as material transformation, measurement, and computational analysis are collected and displayed.
A Collaborative workspace - multiple researchers on a project interact through experiment records, notes, workflow descriptions, and publication.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><landingPage>https://materialscommons.org/mcpub/#/home/top</landingPage><reference pid="10.1007/s11837-016-1998-7">B Puchala, G Tarcea, EA Marquis, M Hedstrom, HV Hagadish, And JE Allison; JOM (2016) 68: 2035</reference></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><dataOrigin><informatics_and_data_science>informatics and data science</informatics_and_data_science></dataOrigin><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://materialscommons.org/mcapp/#/data/home/top</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

This web site is a resource for research, education and collaboration in your science area. It hosts various resources which will help you learn about your science area, including Seminars, Courses, Teaching Materials, and more. These resources come from contributors in our scientific community, and are used by visitors from all over the world.
Most importantly, https://matin.gatech.edu offers live Simulation/Modeling Tools which you can access from your web browser, so you can not only learn about but also simulate your science area.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><landingPage>https://matin.gatech.edu</landingPage><reference pid=""></reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role></Resource>

title: nanomine.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="5T4HEWVJJ5XQOWB30VTV" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>NanoMine</title><altTitle type="AlternativeTitle">NanoMine, Material Informatics for Polymer Nanocomposites</altTitle></identity><providers><publisher>ChiMaD</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><contact><name>http://nanomine.northwestern.edu:8000/contact</name></contact></providers><content><description>Material Informatics for Polymer Nanocomposites

A Nanocomposites Data Resource
This system allows for the registration of materials resources, bridging the gap between existing resources and the end users. NanoMine functions as a centrally located service, making the registered information available for research to the materials community.
NSF supported the initial concept of NanoMine as a joint NU/RPI project through the CDMR program and is currently supporting a robust ontology and software framework via the DIBBS program. NIST/CHIMAD support data curation, tool development, demonstration materials design problems, and integration into the larger MGI network as well as provide backbone use of the Materials Data Curator system run by NIST.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Polymer Nanocomposites</subject><subject>Monte Carlo</subject><landingPage>http://nanomine.northwestern.edu:8000</landingPage><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><dataOrigin><informatics_and_data_science>informatics and data science</informatics_and_data_science></dataOrigin><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><polymers>polymers</polymers></materialType><structuralFeature><composites>composites</composites></structuralFeature><structuralFeature><composites>composites: nanocomposites</composites></structuralFeature><computeScale><nanoscale>atomic scale (nanoscale)</nanoscale></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><title>NanoMine Curation System</title><description>Material Informatics for Polymer Nanocomposites</description><accessURL returns="text/html">http://nanomine.northwestern.edu:8000/</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: natural_fiber_composite_tensile.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="ZSSP7IV0YXUPTY96D1U7" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Statistical behavior of the tensile properties of natural fibre composites</title><version>1.0</version></identity><providers><publisher>University of Queensland</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><contributor role="DataCollector"><name middle="" given="Juan" sur="Torres" xsi:type="PersonName">Juan Pablo Torres</name></contributor><contact><name>Juan Pablo Torres</name><emailAddress>juan.torres@uq.edu.au</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Description of this data

This .zip folder features raw stress-strain tensile data for approximately 500 specimens corresponding to different natural fibre reinforced composite laminates (see Raw Data folder). In addition, we provide here the calculated elastic modulus, strength and failure strain values for each specimen (see Statistics folder). Finally, we include python codes that enables to show the experimental statistical distributions for each material system and calculate the corresponding fit of their probability distribution functions (see Normal.py and Weibull.py files).

The data presented here is associated with the research articles "Statistical behavior of the tensile properties of natural fibre composites" and "The mechanical properties of natural fibre composite laminates: a statistical study" by J.P. Torres, L.-J. Vandi, M. Veidt, M.T. Heiztmann.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Natural fibre composites</subject><landingPage>https://data.mendeley.com/datasets/v25pzywt5c/1</landingPage><reference pid="10.1016/j.dib.2017.03.043">Statistical behavior of the tensile properties of natural fibre composites, Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing, Volume 98, July 2017, Pages 99-104</reference><reference pid="10.1016/j.compositesa.2017.03.010">J.P. Torres, L.-J. Vandi, M. Veidt, M.T. Heiztmann Statistical data for the tensile properties of natural fibre composites Data in Brief, Volume 12, June 2017, Pages 222-226</reference></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><materialType><polymers>polymers</polymers></materialType><structuralFeature><composites>composites</composites></structuralFeature><structuralFeature><composites>composites: fiber-reinforced</composites></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><mechanical>mechanical</mechanical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><mechanical>mechanical: strength</mechanical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><mechanical>mechanical: stress-strain behavior</mechanical></propertyAddressed><characterizationMethod></characterizationMethod><computeScale><mesoscale>mesoscale</mesoscale></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://data.mendeley.com/datasets/v25pzywt5c/1</accessURL></method></access></Resource>
