The atomic The The atomic weights data were published by J. Meija et al in Atomic Weights of the Elements 2013 (http://www.ciaaw.org/atomic-weights.htm), and the isotopic compositions data were published by M. Berglund and M.E. Wieser in Isotopic Compositions of the Elements 2009 (https://www.iupac.org/publications/pac/83/2/0397/). The relative atomic masses of the isotopes data were published by M. Wang, G. Audi, A.H. Wapstra, F.G. Kondev, M. MacCormick, X. Xu1, and B. Pfeiffer in The AME2012 Atomic Mass Evaluation (http://amdc.impcas.ac.cn/evaluation/data2012/ame.html).

Becker</name><emailAddress>potentials@nist.gov</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>This repository provides a source for interatomic potentials (force fields), related files, and evaluation tools to help researchers obtain interatomic models and judge their quality and applicability. Users are encouraged to download and use interatomic potentials, with proper acknowledgement, and developers are welcome to contribute potentials for inclusion. The files provided have been submitted or vetted by their developers and appropriate references are provided. All classes of potentials (e.g., MEAM, ADP, COMB, Reax, EAM, etc.) and materials are welcome. Interatomic potentials and/or related files are currently available for various metals, semiconductors, oxides, and carbon-containing systems.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Materials Engineering</subject><subject>Interatomic Potentials</subject><landingPage>https://www.ctcms.nist.gov/potentials/</landingPage><reference pid=" 10.1016/j.cossms.2013.10.001">C.A. <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="GSC5YEIVNGW0X4BO86I0" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>NIST Spectrum of Th-Ar Hollow Cathode Lamps</title></identity><providers><publisher>NIST</publisher><contributor role="DataCollector"><name middle="" given="Gillian" sur="Nave" xsi:type="PersonName">Gillian Nave</name><affiliation>National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, USA</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="DataCollector"><name middle="" given="Craig" sur="Sansonetti" xsi:type="PersonName">Craig J. Sansonetti</name><affiliation>National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, USA</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="DataCollector"><name middle="" given="Florian" sur="Kerber" xsi:type="PersonName">Florian Kerber</name><affiliation>European Southern Observatory, Karl-Schwarzschild-Str. 2, 85748 Garching, Germany</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="DataCollector"><name middle="" given="Janet" sur="Bass" xsi:type="PersonName">Janet E. Bass</name><affiliation>National Institute of Standards and Technology</affiliation></contributor><contact><name>Gillian Nave</name><emailAddress>gillian.nave@nist.gov</emailAddress><phoneNumber>(301) 975-4311</phoneNumber></contact></providers><content><description>This atlas presents observations of the infra-red (IR) spectrum of a low current Th-Ar hollow cathode lamp with the 2-m Fourier transform spectrometer (FTS) at the National Institute of Standards and Technology. These observations establish more than 2400 lines that are suitable for use as wavelength standards in the range 691 nm to 5804 nm. The observations were made in collaboration with the European Southern Observatory (ESO), in order to provide calibration reference data for new high-resolution Echelle spectrographs, such as the Cryogenic High-Resolution IR Echelle Spectrograph ([CRIRES]), ESO's new IR spectrograph at the Very Large Telescope in Chile. Full details of the measurement and analysis are given in [Kerber et al. (2008)].</description><subject>Astronomy</subject><subject>Near-IR Astronomy</subject><subject>Infrared Spectroscopy</subject><landingPage>https://www.nist.gov/pml/spectrum-th-ar-hollow-cathode-lamps</landingPage><reference pid="">Kerber, F., Nave, G., Sansonetti, "The spectrum of Th-Ar hollow cathode lamps in the 691-5804 nm region: Establishing wavelength standards for the calibration of infrared spectrographs," The Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series, Volume 178, Number 2</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><materialType></materialType><propertyAddressed><optical>optical</optical></propertyAddressed><characterizationMethod><spectrometry>spectrometry</spectrometry></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><spectrometry>spectrometry: IR/FTIR spectrometry</spectrometry></characterizationMethod></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL></termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="text/html">https://physics.nist.gov/PhysRefData/ThArLampAtlas/node9.html</accessURL></method><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="text/html">https://physics.nist.gov/PhysRefData/ThArLampAtlas/asciiDataTwo.txt</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

Powell</name><emailAddress>cedric.powell@nist.gov</emailAddress><phoneNumber>(301) 975-2534</phoneNumber></contact></providers><content><description>The NIST X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) Database gives easy access to the energies of many photoelectron and Auger-electron spectral lines.  Resulting from a critical evaluation of the published literature, the database contains over 22,000 line positions, chemical shifts, doublet splittings, and energy separations of photoelectron and Auger-electron lines.  A highly interactive program allows the user to search by element, line type, line energy, and many other variables.  Users can easily identify unknown measured lines by matching to previous measurements.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy</subject><landingPage>https://srdata.nist.gov/xps/</landingPage><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><materialType><semiconductors>semiconductors</semiconductors></materialType><propertyAddressed><chemical>chemical</chemical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><characterizationMethod><spectroscopy>spectroscopy</spectroscopy></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><spectroscopy>spectroscopy: x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy</spectroscopy></characterizationMethod></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><copyright><crholder>©2012 copyright by the U.S. Secretary of Commerce on behalf of the United States of America. Dragoset</name><affiliation>NIST, Physical Measurement Laboratory</affiliation></contributor><date role="Updated" xsi:type="DciteDate">2005</date><contact><name>Lawrence T. Hudson</name><emailAddress>lawrence.hudson@nist.gov</emailAddress><phoneNumber>(301) 975-2537</phoneNumber></contact></providers><content><description>This x-ray transition table provides the energies for K transitions connecting the K shell (n = 1) to the shells with principal quantum numbers n = 2 to 4 and L transitions connecting the L1, L2, and L3 shells (n = 2) to the shells with principal quantum numbers n = 3 and 4. The elements covered include Z = 10, neon to Z = 100, fermium. There are two unique features of this database: (1) all experimental values are on a scale consistent with the International System of measurement (the SI) and the numerical values are determined using constants from the Recommended Values of the Fundamental Physical Constants: 1998 and (2) accurate theoretical estimates are included for all transitions. The user will find that for many of the transitions, the experimental and theoretical values are very consistent. It is our hope that the theoretical values will provide a useful estimate for missing or poorly measured experimental values.

This database was published in Reviews of Modern Physics, January 2003 in an article titled "X-ray transition energies: new approach to a comprehensive evaluation." In order to respect page limitations, the numerical values are given only in eV and the sorting is only by element. However, the text that discusses the generation of the theoretical and experimental databases provides more details than are given in the text that accompanies this online database.</description><subject>Material Science</subject><subject>Multiconfiguration Dirac–Fock Method</subject><subject>Optical Interferometry</subject><subject>X-ray Diffracrion</subject><landingPage>https://www.nist.gov/pml/x-ray-transition-energies-database</landingPage><reference pid="">R.D. Deslattes, E.G. Kessler, Jr., P. Indelicato, L. de Billy, E. Lindroth, and J. Anton, Rev. Mod. Phys. 75, 35-99 (2003)</reference><reference pid="">P.J. Mohr and B.N. Taylor, Rev. Mod. Phys. 72, 351 (2000); also J. Phys. Chem. Ref. Data 28, 1713 (1999)</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><materialType><semiconductors>semiconductors</semiconductors></materialType><propertyAddressed><chemical>chemical</chemical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><characterizationMethod><optical>optical</optical></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><scattering_and_diffraction>scattering and diffraction</scattering_and_diffraction></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><scattering_and_diffraction>scattering and diffraction: x-ray diffraction</scattering_and_diffraction></characterizationMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://www.nist.gov/pml/x-ray-transition-energies-database</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: nist_fcc_hcp_structures.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="0XXDFG1SP2VJIQLHEFR1" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Elemental vacancy diffusion database from high-throughput first-principles calculations for fcc and hcp structures</title></identity><providers><publisher>NIST</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Thomas" sur="Angsten" xsi:type="PersonName">Angsten, Thomas</name><affiliation>University of Wisconsin-Madison</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Tam" sur="Mayeshiba" xsi:type="PersonName">Mayeshiba, Tam</name><affiliation>University of Wisconsin-Madison</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Henry" sur="Wu" xsi:type="PersonName">Wu, Henry</name><affiliation>University of Wisconsin-Madison</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Dane" sur="Morgan" xsi:type="PersonName">Morgan, Dane</name><affiliation>University of Wisconsin-Madison</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Dane Morgan</name><emailAddress>ddmorgan@wisc.edu</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>This work demonstrates how databases of diffusion-related properties can be developed from high-throughput ab initio calculations. The formation and migration energies for vacancies of all adequately stable pure elements in both the face-centered cubic (fcc) and hexagonal close packing (hcp) crystal structures were determined using ab initio calculations. For hcp migration, both the basal plane and z-direction nearest-neighbor vacancy hops were considered. Energy barriers were successfully calculated for 49 elements in the fcc structure and 44 elements in the hcp structure. These data were plotted against various elemental properties in order to discover significant correlations. The calculated data show smooth and continuous trends when plotted against Mendeleev numbers. The vacancy formation energies were plotted against cohesive energies to produce linear trends with regressed slopes of 0.317 and 0.323 for the fcc and hcp structures respectively. This result shows the expected increase in vacancy formation energy with stronger bonding. The slope of approximately 0.3, being well below that predicted by a simple fixed bond strength model, is consistent with a reduction in the vacancy formation energy due to many-body effects and relaxation. Vacancy migration barriers are found to increase nearly linearly with increasing stiffness, consistent with the local expansion required to migrate an atom. A simple semi-empirical expression is created to predict the vacancy migration energy from the lattice constant and bulk modulus for fcc systems, yielding estimates with errors of approximately 30%. Data notes: Migration barriers may be extracted from NEB static energies (OSZICAR files). Uncorrected vacancy formation energies may be extracted from ep1_static energies compared to bulk_static energies. No POTCAR files are included in the data, but are required for data reproduction. Each OUTCAR file will contain information about the pseudopotential used.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Bulk Diffusion</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><landingPage>http://hdl.handle.net/11256/76</landingPage><reference pid="10.1088/1367-2630/16/1/015018">Angsten T et al (2014) Elemental vacancy diffusion database from high-throughput first-principles calculations for fcc and hcp structures. New J. Phys. 16 015018</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><materialType><semiconductors>semiconductors</semiconductors></materialType><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical: band structure</electrical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><transport>transport</transport></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="text/html">https://materialsdata.nist.gov/dspace/xmlui/handle/11256/76</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="RQJWFN0GK56M7Y30YMGN" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>NIST Heat Transmission Properties of Insulating and Building Materials</title><version>2.0</version></identity><providers><publisher>NIST</publisher><publicationYear>2015</publicationYear><contributor role="DataCollector"><name middle="" given="Robert" sur="Zarr" xsi:type="PersonName">Robert R. Zarr</name><affiliation>NIST</affiliation></contributor><date role="Updated" xsi:type="DciteDate">2016</date><contact><name>Robert R. Zarr</name><emailAddress>robert.zarr@nist.gov</emailAddress><phoneNumber>(301) 975-6436</phoneNumber></contact></providers><content><description>The design of heating, refrigeration, and air-conditioning equipment for buildings as well as components of the building thermal envelope depends on the principles of heat transfer theory. Heat transmission properties, such as thermal conductivity, resistivity, conductance, and resistance, for building materials and thermal insulation are important for the determination of heat transmission coefficients for these applications. The NIST Database on Heat Conductivity of Building Materials provides a valuable reference for building designers, material manufacturers, and researchers in the thermal design of building components and equipment. NIST has accumulated a valuable and comprehensive collection of thermal conductivity data from measurements performed with a 200-mm square guarded-hot-plate apparatus (from 1933 to 1983). The guarded-hot-plate test method is arguably the most accurate and popular method for determination of thermal transmission properties of flat, homogeneous specimens under steady state conditions. Several organizations, including ASTM and ISO, have standardized the method.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Thermodynamics</subject><subject>Heat Transfer</subject><landingPage>https://srdata.nist.gov/insulation/</landingPage><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><propertyAddressed><thermodynamic>thermodynamic</thermodynamic></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><thermodynamic>thermodynamic: heat capacity</thermodynamic></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><thermodynamic>thermodynamic: specific heat</thermodynamic></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><thermodynamic>thermodynamic: thermal conductivity</thermodynamic></propertyAddressed><characterizationMethod></characterizationMethod><computeScale><macroscale>macroscale</macroscale></computeScale><computeScale><mesoscale>mesoscale</mesoscale></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><copyright><crholder>©2017 copyright by the U. This online interface is for convenient, small-scale access; for a more powerful utilization of the data, we recommend downloading the entire database and the API for interfacing with it, from the link below.
 You can...
1) Search for materials by composition,
2) Create phase diagrams using the thermochemical data in OQMD,
3) Determine ground state compounds at any composition,
4) Visualize crystal structures, or
5) Download the entire database (and the API) for your own use!</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><landingPage>http://oqmd.org</landingPage><reference pid="10.1007/s11837-013-0755-4">Saal, J. E., Kirklin, S., Aykol, M., Meredig, B., and Wolverton, C. "Materials Design and Discovery with High-Throughput Density Functional Theory: The Open Quantum Materials Database (OQMD)", JOM 65, 1501-1509 (2013)</reference><reference pid="10.1038/npjcompumats.2015.10">Kirklin, S., Saal, J.E., Meredig, B., Thompson, A., Doak, J.W., Aykol, M., Rühl, S. and Wolverton, C. "The Open Quantum Materials Database (OQMD): assessing the accuracy of DFT formation energies", npj Computational Materials 1, 15010 (2015)</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><nanoscale>atomic scale (nanoscale)</nanoscale></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">http://oqmd.org</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: oxygen_interstitials_deformation.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="4Z78OBLIJBP6C15MITDZ" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Interaction Between Oxygen Interstitials and Deformation Twins in alpha-Titanium</title></identity><providers><publisher>NIST</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="William" sur="Joost" xsi:type="PersonName">Joost, William J.</name><affiliation>University of Maryland</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Sreeramamurthy" sur="Ankem" xsi:type="PersonName">Ankem, Sreeramamurthy</name><affiliation>University of Maryland</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Maija" sur="Kuklja" xsi:type="PersonName">Kuklja, Maija M</name><affiliation>University of Maryland</affiliation></creator><contact><name>William J. Joost</name><emailAddress>william.joost@gmail.com</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>These data files provide input/output VASP and LAMMPS data along with spreadsheets containing data used to produce graphs in our above-reference article. The article abstract is: Twinning is an important deformation mechanism in many hexagonal close packed metals, including alpha-titanium (Ti) alloys. However, the mechanisms for twin nucleation, growth, and interaction with other defects are not completely understood. In this study we interrogate the behavior of oxygen (O) interstitials near a (10-12) twin boundary using a combination of density functional theory (DFT) and modified embedded atom method (MEAM) calculations. The presence of the twin boundary significantly affects both interstitial formation energy as well as the activation barriers for diffusion between sites. We demonstrate that a tetrahedral interstitial is stable in the twin boundary, despite being unstable in bulk Ti, while the formation energies of the octahedral, hexahedral, and crowdion interstitials are all modified by a nearby twin. Further, the activation barriers for diffusion in the region near the twin are uniformly lower than in the bulk. An atom diffusing across the twin boundary moves through several paths with peak activation barriers more than 0.3 eV lower than for comparable diffusion far from the twin, suggesting that the (10-12) twin is a fast diffusion pathway and movement of oxygen interstitials across the twin during twin growth is possible.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject></subject><landingPage>https://materialsdata.nist.gov/dspace/xmlui/handle/11256/272</landingPage><reference pid="10.1016/j.actamat.2015.12.019">Interaction Between Oxygen Interstitials and Deformation Twins in alpha-Titanium, Acta Materialia v. 105 (2016), pp. 44 - 51</reference><reference pid="">W.J. Joost, S. Ankem, and M.M. Kuklja, Mod. Sim. Mat. Sci. and Eng., vol. 23, no. 1, p. 015006, 2015</reference></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys: Ti-containing</metals_and_alloys></materialType><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/us/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://materialsdata.nist.gov/dspace/xmlui/handle/11256/272</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: pppdb.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="KRS49TGUQ8NYSEN9G5Z3" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Polymer Property Predictor and Database</title></identity><providers><publisher>ChiMaD</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><contact><name>ChiMad</name><emailAddress>chimad@northwestern.edu</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>The following are a set of tools created in order to generate phase diagrams for polymer-polymer or polymer-solvent blends using coarse-grain models. These graphs function similarly, varying in their underlying theory and specificity of use. While each of the plot generators vary, the method to generate each plot is roughly the same. For all 3 options, the spinodal curve appears red while the binodal curve appears blue. Each plot has zoom options by drawing a box, or by selecting options on the bottom left of the plot. Also on the bottom right is the current mouse position. The current method of outputting a plot is through matplotlib and mpld3, but this is temporary and another plot generator may be used in the future. All numerical data is generated in simple python.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Polymers</subject><subject>Phase Diagrams</subject><landingPage>http://pppdb.uchicago.edu</landingPage><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><polymers>polymers</polymers></materialType><structuralFeature><phases>phases</phases></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><structural>structural</structural></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><phase-field_calculations>phase-field calculations</phase-field_calculations></computationalMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale><computeScale><structural>structural</structural></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">http://pppdb.uchicago.edu</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: projector_augmented_wave_dft.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="DF3W0ETKCUPMJM51U20K" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Research Data supporting "Linear-Scaling Density Functional Theory using the Projector Augmented Wave Method"</title><identifier>10.5281/zenodo.162501</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>Zenodo</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given=" Nicholas" sur="Hine" xsi:type="PersonName">Nicholas D. M. Hine</name><affiliation>Department of Physics, University of Warwick, Coventry, CV4 7AL, UK</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Nicholas D. M. Hine</name><emailAddress>n.d.m.hine@warwick.ac.uk</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Research Data supporting "Linear-Scaling Density Functional Theory using the Projector Augmented Wave Method" by Nicholas D. M. Hine

Quantum mechanical simulation of realistic models of nanostructured systems, such as nanocrystals and crystalline interfaces, demands computational methods combining high- accuracy with low-order scaling with system size. Blöchl’s projector augmented wave (PAW) approach enables all-electron (AE) calculations with the ef ciency and systematic accuracy of plane-wave pseudopotential calculations. Meanwhile, linear-scaling (LS) approaches
to density functional theory (DFT) allow for simulation of thousands of atoms in feasible computational effort. This article describes an adaptation of PAW for use in the LS-DFT framework provided by the ONETEP LS-DFT package. ONETEP uses optimisation of the density matrix through in situ-optimised local orbitals rather than the direct calculation of eigenstates as in traditional PAW approaches. The method is shown to be comparably accurate to both PAW and AE approaches and to exhibit improved convergence properties compared to norm-conserving pseudopotential methods.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><subject>Linear-scaling</subject><subject>Projector augmented waves</subject><subject>Nanomaterials</subject><subject>Electronic Structure</subject><landingPage>https://zenodo.org/record/162501#.WWWl3MaZPFQ</landingPage><reference pid="10.1088/0953-8984/29/2/024001">Nicholas D M Hine 2017 J. Phys.: Condens. Matter 29 024001</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale><computeScale><nanoscale>atomic scale (nanoscale)</nanoscale></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://zenodo.org/record/162501#.WWWl3MaZPFQ</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

Vargaftik</name><emailAddress>wahr36@gmail.com</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Platinum acetate blue (PAB) of the empirical formula Pt­(OOCMe)2.5±0.25, a byproduct in the synthesis of crystalline platinum­(II) acetate Pt4(OOCMe)8, is an X-ray amorphous substance containing platinum in the oxidation state between (II) and (III). Typical PAB samples were studied with X-ray diffraction, differential thermal analysis–thermogravimetric, extended X-ray absorption fine structure, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, magnetochemistry, and combined quantum chemical density functional theory–molecular mechanics modeling to reveal the main structural features of the PAB molecular building blocks. The applicability of PAB to the synthesis of platinum complexes was demonstrated by the preparation of the new homo- and heteronuclear complexes PtII(dipy)­(OOCMe)2 (1), PtII(μ-OOCMe)4CoII(OH2) (2), and PtIII2(OOCMe)4(O3SPhMe)2 (3) with the use of PAB as starting material.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Inorganic Chemistry</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><subject>X-ray Diffraction</subject><subject>Electron Microscopy</subject><landingPage>https://figshare.com/articles/Platinum_Acetate_Blue_Synthesis_and_Characterization/2263327</landingPage><reference pid="10.1021/ic500940a">Platinum Acetate Blue: Synthesis and Characterization Natalia V. Cherkashina et al. Inorg. Chem., 2014, 53 (16), pp 8397–8406</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><structuralFeature></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><chemical>chemical</chemical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><crystallographic>crystallographic</crystallographic></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><characterizationMethod><microscopy>microscopy</microscopy></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><microscopy>microscopy: scanning electron microscopy</microscopy></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><microscopy>microscopy: transmission electron microscopy</microscopy></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><scattering_and_diffraction>scattering and diffraction: x-ray diffraction</scattering_and_diffraction></characterizationMethod><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><nanoscale>atomic scale (nanoscale)</nanoscale></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://figshare.com/articles/Platinum_Acetate_Blue_Synthesis_and_Characterization/2263327</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: pt_cyanometallate.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="R6Y2OD682UO5NLGJ8UAE" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Cyclometalated Platinum(II) Cyanometallates: Luminescent Blocks for Coordination Self-Assembly</title><identifier>10.1021/acs.inorgchem.7b00006</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>FigShare</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Leon" sur="Schneider" xsi:type="PersonName">Schneider, Leon</name><affiliation>Department of Chemistry, University of Eastern Finland, 80101 Joensuu, Finland</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Vasily" sur="Sivchik" xsi:type="PersonName">Sivchik, Vasily</name><affiliation>Department of Chemistry, University of Eastern Finland, 80101 Joensuu, Finland</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Kun-you" sur="Chung" xsi:type="PersonName">Chung, Kun-you</name><affiliation>Department of Chemistry, National Taiwan University, Taipei 106, Taiwan</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Yi-Ting" sur="Chen" xsi:type="PersonName">Chen, Yi-Ting</name><affiliation>Department of Chemistry, National Taiwan University, Taipei 106, Taiwan</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Antti" sur="Karttunen" xsi:type="PersonName">Karttunen, Antti J.</name><affiliation>Department of Chemistry, Aalto University, FI-00076 Aalto, Finland</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Pi-Tai" sur="Chou" xsi:type="PersonName">Chou, Pi-Tai</name><affiliation>Department of Chemistry, National Taiwan University, Taipei 106, Taiwan</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Igor" sur="Koshevoy" xsi:type="PersonName">Koshevoy, Igor O.</name><affiliation>Department of Chemistry, University of Eastern Finland, 80101 Joensuu, Finland</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Antti J. Karttunen</name><emailAddress>antti.karttunen@aalto.fi</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>A family of cyanide-bridged heterometallic aggregates has been constructed of the chromophoric cycloplatinated metalloligands and coordinatively unsaturated d10 fragments {M­(PPh3)n}. The tetranuclear complexes of general composition [Pt­(C^N)­(CN)2M­(PPh3)2]2 [C^N = ppy, M = Cu (1), Ag (2); C^N = tolpy (Htolpy = 2-(4-tolyl)-pyridine), M = Cu (4), Ag (5); C^N = F2ppy (HF2ppy = 2-(4, 6-difluorophenyl)-pyridine), M = Cu (7), Ag (8)] demonstrate a squarelike arrangement of the molecular frameworks, which is achieved due to favorable coordination geometries of the bridging ligands and the metal ions. Variation of the amount of the ancillary phosphine (for M = Ag) afforded compounds [Pt­(C^N)­(CN)2Ag­(PPh3)]2 (C^N = ppy, 3; C^N = tolpy, 6); for the latter one an alternative cluster topology, stabilized by the Pt–Ag metallophilic and η1-Cipso(C^N)–Ag bonding, was observed. The solid-state structures of all of the title species 1–8 were determined crystallographically. The complexes exhibit moderately strong room-temperature phosphorescence as crystalline powders (Φem = 16–34%, λem = 470–511 nm). The luminescence studies and time-dependent density functional theory computational analysis indicate that the photophysical behavior is dominated by the 3π–π* electronic transitions localized on the cyclometalated fragment and mixed with MPtLCT contribution, while the d10-phosphine motifs have a negligible contribution into the frontier orbitals and therefore show a little influence on the emission performance of the described compounds.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Luminescence</subject><landingPage>https://figshare.com/collections/Cyclometalated_Platinum_II_Cyanometallates_Luminescent_Blocks_for_Coordination_Self-Assembly/3730237</landingPage><reference pid="10.1021/acs.inorgchem.7b00006">Cyclometalated Platinum(II) Cyanometallates: Luminescent Blocks for Coordination Self-Assembly Leon Schneider et al. Inorg. Chem., 2017, 56 (8), pp 4459–4467</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><organometallics>organometallics</organometallics></materialType><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><optical>optical: luminescence</optical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><structural>structural</structural></propertyAddressed><characterizationMethod><scattering_and_diffraction>scattering and diffraction</scattering_and_diffraction></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><scattering_and_diffraction>scattering and diffraction: x-ray diffraction</scattering_and_diffraction></characterizationMethod><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale><computeScale><structural>structural</structural></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://figshare.com/collections/Cyclometalated_Platinum_II_Cyanometallates_Luminescent_Blocks_for_Coordination_Self-Assembly/3730237</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="3O5GOKI1AB4EOH2MXJIP" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Quantum Machine - MD Trajectories of C7O2H10</title></identity><providers><publisher>Quantum-machine</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Kristof " sur="Schütt" xsi:type="PersonName">Kristof T Schütt</name><affiliation>Technische Universität Berlin , Berlin · Department of Software Engineering and Theoretical Computer Science</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Farhad" sur="Arbabzadah" xsi:type="PersonName">Farhad Arbabzadah</name><affiliation>Machine Learning Group, Technische Universität Berlin, Marchstr. 23, 10587 Berlin, Germany</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Stefan" sur="Chmiela" xsi:type="PersonName">Stefan Chmiela</name><affiliation>Machine Learning Group, Technische Universität Berlin, Marchstr. 23, 10587 Berlin, Germany</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Klaus" sur="Müller" xsi:type="PersonName">Klaus R. Müller</name><affiliation>Machine Learning Group, Technische Universität Berlin, Marchstr. 23, 10587 Berlin, Germany</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Alexandre" sur="Tkatchenko" xsi:type="PersonName">Alexandre Tkatchenko</name><affiliation>Theory Department, Fritz-Haber-Institut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Faradayweg 4-6, D-14195 Berlin, Germany</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Alexandre Tkatchenko</name><postalAddress><addressLine>Theory Department, Fritz-Haber-Institut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Faradayweg 4-6, D-14195 Berlin, Germany</addressLine></postalAddress></contact></providers><content><description>This data set consists of molecular dynamics trajectories of 113 randomly selected C7O2H10 isomers calculated at a temperature of 500 K and resolution of 1fs using density functional theory with the PBE exchange-correlation potential.

C7O2H10 is the largest set of isomer of QM9. Identifiers used in this data set agree with those used in the QM9 isomer subset.

Each trajectory is stored in a xyz-file named id.xyz with corresponding energies in id.energy.dat. Additionally, consistent energy calculations of all isomers in equilibrium (according to QM9) are provided in c7o2h10_equilibrium.dat.
Benchmark

Mean abs. errors for energy prediction using the equilibrium energies as well as 50% of each trajectory as reference calculations for training (in eV).</description><subject>Physical chemistry</subject><subject>Computational chemistry</subject><subject>Molecular Dynamics</subject><subject>Machine Learning</subject><landingPage>http://quantum-machine.org/datasets/</landingPage><reference pid="10.1038/ncomms13890">Quantum-Chemical Insights from Deep Tensor Neural Networks, Kristof T. Schütt et al., arXiv:1609.08259 , Nature Comm. 8, 13890 (2017)</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><organic_compounds>organic compounds</organic_compounds></materialType><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><molecular_dynamics>molecular dynamics</molecular_dynamics></computationalMethod></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">http://quantum-machine.org/datasets/</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="S0BHSE1FYAVFG6OWT79F" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Uniting Ruthenium(II) and Platinum(II) Polypyridine Centers in Heteropolymetallic Complexes Giving Strong Two-Photon Absorption</title><identifier>10.1021/acs.inorgchem.5b02089</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>FigShare</publisher><publicationYear>2015</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Pengfei" sur="Shi" xsi:type="PersonName">Shi, Pengfei</name><affiliation>School of Chemistry, Huaihai Institute of Technology, Cangwu Road, Lianyungang 222005, P. R. China</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Benjamin" sur="Coe" xsi:type="PersonName">Coe, Benjamin J.</name><affiliation>School of Chemistry, The University of Manchester, Oxford Road, Manchester M13 9PL, United Kingdom</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Sergio" sur="Sánchez" xsi:type="PersonName">Sánchez, Sergio</name><affiliation>School of Chemistry, The University of Manchester, Oxford Road, Manchester M13 9PL, United Kingdom</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Daqi" sur="Wang" xsi:type="PersonName">Wang, Daqi</name><affiliation>School of Chemistry, Liaocheng University, Hunan Road, Liaocheng 252000, P. R. China</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Yupeng" sur="Tian" xsi:type="PersonName">Tian, Yupeng</name><affiliation>School of Chemistry, Anhui University, Jiulong Road, Hefei 230601, P. R. China</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Marcin" sur="Nyk" xsi:type="PersonName">Nyk, Marcin</name><affiliation>Advanced Materials Engineering and Modelling Group, Faculty of Chemistry, Wrocław University of Technology, Wybrzeże Wyspiańskiego 27, 50-370 Wrocław, Poland</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Marek" sur="Samoc" xsi:type="PersonName">Samoc, Marek</name><affiliation>Advanced Materials Engineering and Modelling Group, Faculty of Chemistry, Wrocław University of Technology, Wybrzeże Wyspiańskiego 27, 50-370 Wrocław, Poland</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Pengfei Shi</name><emailAddress>shipf@hhit.edu.cn</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>New trinuclear RuPt2 and heptanuclear RuPt6 complex salts are prepared by attaching PtII 2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine (tpy) moieties to RuII 4,4′:2′,2″:4″,4‴-quaterpyridine (qpy) complexes. Characterization includes single crystal X-ray structures for both polymetallic species. The visible absorption bands are primarily due to RuII → qpy metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) transitions, according to time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) calculations. These spectra change only slightly on Pt coordination, while the orange-red emission from the complexes shows corresponding small red-shifts, accompanied by decreases in intensity. Cubic molecular nonlinear optical behavior has been assessed by using Z-scan measurements. These reveal relatively high two-photon absorption (2PA) cross sections σ2, with maximal values of 301 GM at 834 nm (RuPt2) and 523 GM at 850 nm (RuPt6) when dissolved in methanol or acetone, respectively. Attaching PtII(tpy) moieties triples or quadruples the 2PA activities when compared with the RuII-based cores.</description><subject>Physical Chemistry</subject><subject>Polypyridine Complexes</subject><subject>X-ray Crystallography</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><landingPage>https://figshare.com/collections/Uniting_Ruthenium_II_and_Platinum_II_Polypyridine_Centers_in_Heteropolymetallic_Complexes_Giving_Strong_Two_Photon_Absorption/2204182</landingPage><reference pid="10.1021/acs.inorgchem.5b02089">Uniting Ruthenium(II) and Platinum(II) Polypyridine Centers in Heteropolymetallic Complexes Giving Strong Two-Photon Absorption, Inorg. Chem., 2015, 54 (23), pp 11450–11456Shi et al.</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><experiments>experiments</experiments></dataOrigin><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><organic_compounds>organic compounds</organic_compounds></materialType><structuralFeature></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><structural>structural</structural></propertyAddressed><characterizationMethod><scattering_and_diffraction>scattering and diffraction: x-ray diffraction</scattering_and_diffraction></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><spectrometry>spectrometry</spectrometry></characterizationMethod><characterizationMethod><spectrometry>spectrometry: energy dispersive x-ray spectometry</spectrometry></characterizationMethod><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale><computeScale><structural>structural</structural></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://figshare.com/collections/Uniting_Ruthenium_II_and_Platinum_II_Polypyridine_Centers_in_Heteropolymetallic_Complexes_Giving_Strong_Two_Photon_Absorption/2204182</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="5YNHOS6C8S1RP1177OKW" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>On the calculation of second-order magnetic properties using subsystem approaches in the relativistic framework - supplementary information</title><version></version><identifier>10.5281/zenodo.179720</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>Zenodo</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Malgorzata" sur="Olejniczak" xsi:type="PersonName">Malgorzata Olejniczak</name><affiliation>Universit ́e de Lille, CNRS, UMR 8523 – PhLAM – Physique des Lasers, Atomes et Mol ́ecules, F-59000 Lille</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Radovan" sur="Bast" xsi:type="PersonName">Radovan Bast</name><affiliation>High Performance Computing Group, UiT The Arctic University of Norway, N–9037 Tromsœ, Norway</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Andre" sur="Gomes" xsi:type="PersonName">Andre Severo Pereira Gomes</name><affiliation>Universit ́e de Lille, CNRS, UMR 8523 – PhLAM – Physique des Lasers, Atomes et Mol ́ecules, F-59000 Lille</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Andre Severo Pereira Gomes</name><emailAddress>andre.gomes@univ-lille1.fr</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Supplementary information to the publication "On the calculation of second-order magnetic properties using subsystem approaches in the relativistic framework"

The attached 'supplementary_info_fde_mag.zip' unpacks to three directories:

    'optimized_structures' directory contains optimized molecular structures in xyz format
    'results' directory contains all the results obtained in this work, collected in
        gnumeric and xlsx spreadsheets with complete results from DIRAC and from ADF
        csv files (data involving heavy atoms, X, and hydrogen-bonded H atoms, Hb)
        'supplementary_tables' latex and pdf files
    'visualization' directory contains the data for plotting the NMR shielding density and prepared plots; for the explanation of files in this directory open the 'visualization/visualization.html' document in your browser or read the corresponding jupyter notebook (visualization/visualization.ipynb')</description><subject>Chemical Physics</subject><subject>Nuclear Magnetic Resonance</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><landingPage>https://zenodo.org/record/179720#.WWWlTsaZPFQ</landingPage><reference pid="10.1039/C6CP08561J">On the calculation of second-order magnetic properties using subsystem approaches in the relativistic framework, Olejniczak et al. arXiv:1610.04280</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://zenodo.org/record/179720#.WWWlTsaZPFQ</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: strain_effects_oxygen.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="13HQ3IJJ1MVAY9PLXXTN" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Strain effects on oxygen migration in perovskites: La[Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Ga]O3</title></identity><providers><publisher>NIST</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Tam" sur="Mayeshiba" xsi:type="PersonName">Mayeshiba, Tam</name><affiliation>University of Wisconsin-Madison</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Dane" sur="Morgan" xsi:type="PersonName">Morgan, Dane</name><affiliation>University of Wisconsin-Madison</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Dane Morgan</name><emailAddress>ddmorgan@wisc.edu</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Fast oxygen transport materials are necessary for a range of technologies, including efficient and cost-effective solid oxide fuel cells, gas separation membranes, oxygen sensors, chemical looping devices, and memristors. Strain is often proposed as a method to enhance the performance of oxygen transport materials, but the magnitude of its effect and its underlying mechanisms are not well-understood, particularly in the widely-used perovskite-structured oxygen conductors. This work reports on an ab initio prediction of strain effects on migration energetics for nine perovskite systems of the form LaBO3, where B = [Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Ga]. Biaxial strain, as might be easily produced in epitaxial systems, is predicted to lead to approximately linear changes in migration energy. We find that tensile biaxial strain reduces the oxygen vacancy migration barrier across the systems studied by an average of 66 meV per percent strain for a single selected hop, with a low of 36 and a high of 89 meV decrease in migration barrier per percent strain across all systems. The estimated range for the change in migration barrier within each system is +/- 25 meV per percent strain when considering all hops. These results suggest that strain can significantly impact transport in these materials, e. g., a 2% tensile strain can increase the diffusion coefficient by about three orders of magnitude at 300 K (one order of magnitude at 500 degrees C or 773 K) for one of the most strain-responsive materials calculated here (LaCrO3). We show that a simple elasticity model, which assumes only dilative or compressive strain in a cubic environment and a fixed migration volume, can qualitatively but not quantitatively model the strain dependence of the migration energy, suggesting that factors not captured by continuum elasticity play a significant role in the strain response.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><subject>Physical Chemistry</subject><subject>Chemical Physics</subject><landingPage>https://materialsdata.nist.gov/dspace/xmlui/handle/11256/701</landingPage><reference pid="10.1039/c4cp05554c">Mayeshiba, T. and Morgan, D. Strain effects on oxygen migration in perovskites. Physical chemistry chemical physics : PCCP 17, 2715-2721 (2015)</reference><reference pid="10.1039/c6cp90050j ">Mayeshiba, T. and Morgan, D. Correction: Strain effects on oxygen migration in perovskites. Physical chemistry chemical physics : PCCP (2016)</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><structuralFeature></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://materialsdata.nist.gov/dspace/xmlui/handle/11256/701</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

Persson</name><affiliation>Energy Technologies Area, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Berkeley, California 94720, USA</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Shyue Ping" sur="Ong" xsi:type="PersonName">Shyue Ping Ong</name><affiliation>Department of NanoEngineering, University of California San Diego, 9500 Gilman Dr, Mail Code 0448, La Jolla, California 92093-0448, USA</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Shyue Ping Ong</name><emailAddress>s2ong@ucsd.edu</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>This file contains the surface energies and related properties of elemental crystals computed using density functional theory calculations. The relevant outputs generated from these calculations have also been included in this file.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><subject>Surfaces</subject><subject>Interfaces and Thin Films</subject><landingPage>http://datadryad.org/resource/doi:10.5061/dryad.f2n6f</landingPage><reference pid="10.1038/sdata.2016.80">Tran R, Xu Z, Radhakrishnan B, Winston D, Sun W, Persson KA, Ong SP (2016) Surface energies of elemental crystals. Scientific Data 3, Article number: 160080 (2016)</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType></materialType><structuralFeature></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><thermodynamic>thermodynamic: surface energies</thermodynamic></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">http://datadryad.org/resource/doi:10.5061/dryad.f2n6f</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: ti_o_fitting_db.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="74DCN6V9H95BN5TWCOZS" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Fitting database entries for a modified embedded atom method potential for interstitial oxygen in titanium</title><identifier>http://hdl.handle.net/11256/782</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>NIST</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Dallas" sur="Trinkle" xsi:type="PersonName">Trinkle, Dallas R.</name><affiliation>University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, USA</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Pinchao " sur="Zhang" xsi:type="PersonName">Zhang, Pinchao</name><affiliation>University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, USA</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Dallas R. Trinkle</name><emailAddress>dtrinkle@illinois.edu</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Modeling oxygen interstitials in titanium requires a new empirical potential. We optimize potential parameters using a fitting database of first-principle oxygen interstitial energies and forces. A new database optimization algorithm based on Bayesian sampling is applied to obtain an optimal potential for a specific testing set of density functional data. A parallel genetic algorithm minimizes the sum of logistic function evaluations of the testing set predictions. We test the transferability of the potential model against oxygen interstitials in HCP titanium, transition barriers between oxygen interstitial sites, oxygen in the titanium prismatic stacking fault. The potential is applicable to oxygen interaction with the titanium screw dislocation, and predicts that the interactions between oxygen and the dislocation core is weak and short-ranged.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><landingPage>https://materialsdata.nist.gov/dspace/xmlui/handle/11256/782</landingPage><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys: Ti-containing</metals_and_alloys></materialType><structuralFeature><defects>defects</defects></structuralFeature><structuralFeature><defects>defects: dislocations</defects></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><nanoscale>atomic scale (nanoscale)</nanoscale></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/us/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://materialsdata.nist.gov/dspace/xmlui/handle/11256/782</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

Joost</name><emailAddress>wjoost@umd.edu</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>These data files correspond to our publication listed above. The files included here are: 1) LAMMPS and VASP input files describing the structures specified in the article. 2) LAMMPS and VASP output files describing the calculation results and the output structures. 3) A Python script used in this study to perform a brute force search of the parameter space for the Ti-O MEAM potential. Further details are provided in the article, and in the script. 4) The Ti, O and Ti-O potential files in LAMMPS MEAM format.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><landingPage>https://materialsdata.nist.gov/dspace/xmlui/handle/11115/244</landingPage><reference pid="10.1088/0965-0393/23/1/015006">W.J. title: tricyclic_fused_cyclopropanes.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="9HBK6OT3NVFFWMG6WU4W" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>A Counterion-Directed Approach To The Diels-Alder Paradigm: Cascade Synthesis Of Tricyclic Fused Cyclopropanes</title><identifier>10.5281/zenodo.60147</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>Zenodo</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Robert" sur="Paton" xsi:type="PersonName">Paton, Robert S.</name><affiliation>Chemistry Research Laboratory, University of Oxford, Oxford, UK</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Robert S. Paton</name><emailAddress>robert.paton@chem.ox.ac.uk</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>An approach to the intramolecular Diels–Alder reaction has led to a cascade synthesis of complex carbocycles composed of three fused rings and up to five stereocenters with complete stereocontrol. Computational analysis reveals that the reaction proceeds by a Michael/Michael/cyclopropanation/epimerization cascade in which size and coordination of the counterion is key.

Supporting Information: DFT optimised structures as described in the title paper.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><subject>Computational Chemistry</subject><landingPage>https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.60147</landingPage><reference pid="10.1002/anie.201608534">A Counterion-Directed Approach to the Diels–Alder Paradigm: Cascade Synthesis of Tricyclic Fused Cyclopropanes, Kiss et al., Angewandte Chemie, Volume 55, Issue 44 October 24, 2016 Pages 13813–13817</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><organic_compounds>organic compounds</organic_compounds></materialType><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.60147</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

Fellinger</name><emailAddress>mfelling@illinois.edu</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>We present computed datasets on changes in the lattice parameter and elastic stiffness coefficients of bcc Fe due to substitutional Al, B, Cu, Mn, and Si solutes, and octahedral interstitial C and N solutes. The data is calculated using the methodology based on density functional theory (DFT) presented in Ref. (M.R. Fellinger, L.G. Hector Jr., D.R. Trinkle, 2017). All the DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab initio Simulations Package (VASP) (G. Kresse, J. Furthmüller, 1996).

1. VASP input and output text files 2. PureFe.csv file containing computed data for pure bcc Fe 3. SoluteEffects.csv file containing computed solute effects on the lattice parameter and elastic stiffness coefficients of bcc Fe 4. Text files containing UNIX shell scripts that compute the data from the VASP output files</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Computational Materials Science</subject><landingPage>http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2352340916307521</landingPage><reference pid="10.1016/j.commatsci.2016.09.040">Ab initio calculations of the lattice parameter and elastic stiffness coefficients of bcc Fe with solutes, M.R. <Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="NWFID3V0R1AEOZK25YJE" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>NIST Alloy Data</title><altTitle type="AlternativeTitle">NIST Thermodynamic Research Center</altTitle></identity><providers><publisher>NIST Thermodynamic Research Center</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><creator><name label="IsCitedBy" xsi:type="DciteRelation">Thermodynamic Research Center</name></creator><contact><name>Thermodynamic Research Center</name><emailAddress>TRCalloy@nist.gov</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>The NIST Alloy Data web application provides access to thermophysical property data with a focus on unary, binary, and ternary metal systems. All data is from original experimental publications including full provenance and uncertainty.

For 75 years, the Thermodynamic Research Center has produced data resources to support scientific research and industrial process design. Located in Boulder, Colorado, TRC seeks to:
1) Collect and curate a comprehensive archive of experimental thermophysical and thermochemical property data 
2) Serve as a comprehensive source of critically evaluated data for scientific and industrial applications
Under the auspices of the Materials Genome Initiative, TRC has extended its infrastructure to the field of material science - developing a framework for archiving experimental data from the scientific literature and disseminating those data to the scientific community.
For more information, please visit us at http://trc.nist.gov/.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Metal Systems</subject><landingPage>http://trc.nist.gov/applications/metals_data/metals_data.php</landingPage><reference pid="10.1063/1.4942634">E. title: analyzing_xray_tomographies.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="T5GESJUOBHPAQN937KCA" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Dataset accompanying the article: Analyzing X-Ray tomographies of granular packings</title><identifier>10.5281/zenodo.556515</identifier></identity><providers><publisher>Zenodo</publisher><publicationYear>2017</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Simon" sur="Weis" xsi:type="PersonName">Weis, Simon</name><affiliation>Institut für Theoretische Physik I, Friedrich-Alexander-Universität, 91058 Erlangen, Germany</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Matthias" sur="Schröter" xsi:type="PersonName">Schröter, Matthias</name><affiliation>Institute for Multiscale Simulation, Friedrich-Alexander-Universität, 91052 Erlangen, Germany</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Simon Weis</name><emailAddress>simon.weis@fau.de</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>This dataset (and the added analysis software) belong to the article:  Analyzing X-Ray tomographies of granular packings in Review of Scientific Instruments.

The abstract of the article: Starting from three-dimensional volume data of a granular packing, as e.g. obtained by X-ray Computed Tomography, we discuss methods to first detect the individual particles in the sample and then analyze their properties. This analysis includes the pair correlation function, the volume and shape of the Voronoi cells and the number and type of contacts formed between individual particles. We mainly focus on packings of monodisperse spheres, but we will also comment on other monoschematic particles such as ellipsoids and tetrahedra. This paper is accompanied by a package of free software containing all programs (including source code) and an example three-dimensional dataset which allows the reader to reproduce and modify all examples given.</description><subject>Software</subject><subject>Image Processing</subject><subject>X-ray Tomography</subject><landingPage>https://zenodo.org/record/556515</landingPage><reference pid="10.1063/1.4983051">Analyzing X-Ray tomographies of granular packings Simon Weis, Matthias Schröter, arXiv:1612.06639</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><informatics_and_data_science>informatics and data science</informatics_and_data_science></dataOrigin><computationalMethod></computationalMethod><synthesisProcessing></synthesisProcessing></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://zenodo.org/record/556515</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

title: au_nanocluster_dft.xml
content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="AB4PXCG428UACA3JXL62" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Unraveling the Planar-Globular Transition in Gold Nanoclusters through Evolutionary Search</title></identity><providers><publisher>Argonne National Laboratory</publisher><publicationYear>2016</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Alper" sur="Kinaci" xsi:type="PersonName">Alper Kinaci</name><affiliation>Center for Nanoscale Materials, Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, IL 60439 USA</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Badri" sur="Narayanan" xsi:type="PersonName">Badri Narayanan</name><affiliation>Center for Nanoscale Materials, Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, IL 60439 USA</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Fatih" sur="Sen" xsi:type="PersonName">Fatih G. Sen</name><affiliation>Center for Nanoscale Materials, Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, IL 60439 USA</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Michael" sur="Davis" xsi:type="PersonName">Michael J. Davis</name></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Stephen" sur="Gray" xsi:type="PersonName">Stephen K. Gray</name><affiliation>Center for Nanoscale Materials, Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, IL 60439 USA</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Subramanian" sur="Sankaranarayanan" xsi:type="PersonName">Subramanian K.R.S. Sankaranarayanan</name><affiliation>Center for Nanoscale Materials, Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, IL 60439 USA</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Maria" sur="Chan" xsi:type="PersonName">Maria K.Y. Chan</name><affiliation>Center for Nanoscale Materials, Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, IL 60439 USA</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Maria K. Y. Chan</name><emailAddress>mchan@anl.gov</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Au nanoclusters are of technological relevance for catalysis, photonics, sensors, and of fundamental scientific interest owing to planar to globular structural transformation at an anomalously high number of atoms i.e. in the range 12–14. The nature and causes of this transition remain a mystery. In order to unravel this conundrum, high throughput density functional theory (DFT) calculations, coupled with a global structural optimization scheme based on a modified genetic algorithm (GA) are conducted. More than 20,000 Au12, Au13, and Au14 nanoclusters are evaluated. With any DFT functional, globular and planar structures coexist across the size range of interest. The planar-globular transition is gradual at room temperature rather than a sharp transition as previously believed. The effects of anionicity, s-d band hybridization and long range interactions on the dimensional transition are quantified by using the structures adjacent to the minima. Anionicity marginally changes the relative stability of the clusters. The degree of s-d hybridization is varied via changing the Hubbard U value which corroborate that s-d hybridization alone does not stabilize planar structures. van der Waals interactions, on the other hand, stabilize globular structures. These results elucidate the balance between the different reasons of the dimensional transition in gold nanoclusters.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Nanoclusters</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><subject>Genetic Algorithm</subject><landingPage>https://www.nature.com/articles/srep34974#abstract</landingPage><reference pid="10.1038/srep34974">Unraveling the Planar-Globular Transition in Gold Nanoclusters through Evolutionary Search, Kinaci et al. Scientific Reports 6, Article number: 34974 (2016)</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType></materialType><structuralFeature><morphologies>morphologies: clusters</morphologies></structuralFeature><propertyAddressed><electrical>electrical</electrical></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://www.nature.com/articles/srep34974#abstract</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

Gibson</name><affiliation>Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 77 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA, USA</affiliation></contributor><contributor role="DataCollector"><name middle="" given="Christopher" sur="Schuh" xsi:type="PersonName">Christopher A. Schuh</name><affiliation>Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 77 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA, USA</affiliation></contributor><contact><name>Michael A. Gibson</name><emailAddress>ude.tim@nosbig_m</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Segregation-induced changes in interfacial cohesion often control the mechanical properties of metals. The change in the work of separation of an interface upon segregation of a solute to the interface, termed the embrittling potency, is an atomic-level quantity used to predict and understand embrittlement phenomena. We present a compilation of calculations of embrittling potencies, along with references for these calculations. A discussion of this data is made in a separate article (Gibson and Schuh, 2016).</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Ab-Initio Calculation</subject><subject>Surface Segregation</subject><landingPage>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4706572/</landingPage><reference pid="10.1016/j.scriptamat.2015.09.041">Gibson M.A., Schuh C.A., A survey of ab-initio calculations shows that segregation-induced grain boundary embrittlement is predicted by bond-breaking arguments. <Resource xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" localid="MOCX7S4YNHUFZ5DK6B8F" status="active" xmlns="http://schema.nist.gov/xml/res-md/1.0wd-02-2017"><identity><title>Data set for diffusion coefficients of alloying elements in dilute Mg alloys from first-principles</title></identity><providers><publisher>NCBI</publisher><publicationYear>2015</publicationYear><creator><name middle="" given="Bi-Cheng" sur="Zhou" xsi:type="PersonName">Bi-Cheng Zhou</name><affiliation>Department of Materials Science and Engineering, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, USA</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Shun-Li" sur="Shang" xsi:type="PersonName">Shun-Li Shang</name><affiliation>Department of Materials Science and Engineering, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, USA</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Yi" sur="Wang" xsi:type="PersonName">Yi Wang</name><affiliation>Department of Materials Science and Engineering, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, USA</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Zi-Kui" sur="Liu" xsi:type="PersonName">Zi-Kui Liu</name><affiliation>Department of Materials Science and Engineering, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, USA</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Bi-Cheng Zhou</name><emailAddress>bicheng.zhou@psu.edu</emailAddress></contact></providers><content><description>Diffusion coefficients of alloying elements in Mg are critical for the development of new Mg alloys for lightweight applications. Here we present the data set of the temperature-dependent dilute tracer diffusion coefficients for 47 substitutional alloying elements in hexagonal closed packed (hcp) Mg calculated from first-principles calculations based on density functional theory (DFT) by combining transition state theory and an 8-frequency model. Benchmark for the DFT calculations and systematic comparison with experimental diffusion data are also presented. The data set refers to “Diffusion coefficients of alloying elements in dilute Mg alloys: A comprehensive first-principles study” by Zhou et al.</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><subject>Diffusion</subject><landingPage>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4669471/</landingPage><reference pid="10.1016/j.actamat.2015.10.010">Diffusion coefficients of alloying elements in dilute Mg alloys: A comprehensive first-principles study, Zhou et al., Acta Mater. 2016;103:573–586</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys: Mg-containing</metals_and_alloys></materialType><propertyAddressed><transport>transport</transport></propertyAddressed><propertyAddressed><transport>transport: tracer diffusivity</transport></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod><computeScale><electronic>electronic</electronic></computeScale><computeScale><nanoscale>atomic scale (nanoscale)</nanoscale></computeScale></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4669471/</accessURL></method></access></Resource>

China</affiliation></creator><creator><name middle="" given="Xiangying" sur="Meng" xsi:type="PersonName">Xiangying Meng</name><affiliation>College of Sciences, Northeastern University, Shenyang 110819, China, Key Laboratory for Anisotropy and Texture of Materials (MOE), Northeastern University, Shenyang 110819, China</affiliation></creator><contact><name>Xiangying Meng</name><postalAddress><addressLine>College of Sciences, Northeastern University, Shenyang 110819, China</addressLine></postalAddress><emailAddress>x_y_meng@mail.neu.edu.cn</emailAddress><phoneNumber>+86 24 83681159</phoneNumber></contact></providers><content><description>The compositions and structures of thermodynamically stable or metastable precipitations in binary Mg-X (X=Sn, Y, Sc, Ag) alloys are predicted using ab-initio evolutionary algorithm. The geometry optimizations of the predicted intermetallic compounds are carried out in the framework of density functional theory (DFT). A complete list of the optimized crystallographic information (in cif format) of the predicted intermetallic phases is presented here. The data is related to “Predictions on the compositions, structures, and mechanical properties of intermediate phases in binary Mg–X (X=Sn, Y, Sc, Ag ) alloys” by Liu et al..</description><subject>Materials Science</subject><subject>Density Functional Theory</subject><landingPage>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4510453/</landingPage><reference pid="10.1016/j.commatsci.2015.04.038">Liu  et al., Comput. Mater. Sci. Volume 106, August 2015, Pages 180-187</reference><primaryAudience>research</primaryAudience></content><role xsi:type="Dataset"><type>Dataset</type></role><applicability><dataOrigin><simulations>simulations</simulations></dataOrigin><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys</metals_and_alloys></materialType><materialType><metals_and_alloys>metals and alloys: Mg-containing</metals_and_alloys></materialType><propertyAddressed></propertyAddressed><computationalMethod><density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure>density functional theory or electronic structure</density_functional_theory_or_electronic_structure></computationalMethod></applicability><access><policy><restriction>public</restriction><termsURL>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</termsURL></policy><method xsi:type="DownloadMethod"><accessURL returns="">https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4510453/</accessURL></method></access></Resource>
